document_summary: The document is the EPA’s 2026 Pesticide General Permit (PGP) establishing national NPDES authorization, application forms, and compliance requirements for discharges from pesticide applications (effective Oct 31, 2026–Oct 30, 2031). It defines who must file Notices of Intent (NOI) and Notices of Termination (NOT), electronic reporting via EPA’s NeT (with limited waivers), and specifies PDMP, PDEW, and annual-reporting obligations (large entities and certain small entities), recordkeeping (3‑year retention) and visual-monitoring requirements. The permit sets technology- and water-quality-based limits (prohibiting discharges to waters impaired for an active ingredient and limiting Tier 3/ONRW impacts), detailed adverse-incident and spill reporting (24‑hour notification and 30‑day written reports), and corrective-action/PDMP revision rules. It requires ESA eligibility per Criteria A–G using EPA mapping tools and prescribes consultations, documentation, and special handling for Declared Pest Emergencies. Appendix and Part 9 regional/tribal conditions add state- and tribe-specific requirements (notably New Mexico antidegradation and Pueblo notice rules, and Washington/Region 10 aquatic-use restrictions, timing windows, and signage), plus full contact/mailing addresses and standard permit conditions.

section_summaries.9.0 Permit Conditions Applicable Within: All Notices (NOIs/NOTs), reports, analytical data and related correspondence with EPA must be sent concurrently to the Pueblo of Isleta (Environment Department, Tribal Water Quality Control Officer) by email and U.S. Mail. Electronic copies of submissions are also required for actions within 8 river miles upstream of the Pueblo boundary. Restricted-use pesticides are prohibited within the Pueblo’s exterior boundaries, and the Pueblo may impose more stringent action thresholds; requirements are authorized by the Pueblo of Isleta Surface Water Quality Standards (POI SWQS).

Decision-makers covered by the PGP must electronically send Notice of Intent (NOI) and, within three business days of EPA confirmation, the Notice of Termination (NOT) to the Pueblo of Sandia Environmental Department (Greg Kaufman: gkaufman@sandiapueblo.nsn.us; Cynthia King: cking@sandiapueblo.nsn.us). Those required to prepare a Pesticide Discharge Management Plan (PDMP) must provide an electronic copy 10 days before pesticide application; these notifications are intended to ensure compliance with the Pueblo of Sandia Water Quality Standards (2023), including the Wildlife Habitat Total DDT standard (0.001 µg/L) and other pesticide-related toxic substance limits.

Defines footnote symbols (e.g., * = criteria assume fish consumption but not regular water ingestion; -- = no criterion; hd = hardness; ln = natural log) and states carcinogen criteria are based on a 1×10⁻⁶ risk and, where fish-based criteria are absent, MCLs or background levels are used. New EPA toxic substance criteria will be adopted during triennial review and apply equally; site-specific criterion adjustments may be made with public participation and EPA approval, and pesticides/PCBs require sediment and tissue monitoring with investigations triggered when fish tissue exceeds FDA Action Limits.

Under Condition #6 (Notice of Intent Requirements), 20.6.4.7(S)(5) NMAC (definition d. Pueblo of Taos) specifies that there are no additional NOI requirements for the Pueblo of Taos beyond the standard permit conditions.

Decision-makers must send a copy of the NOI to EPA and to the Santa Clara Pueblo Environment Director (dnoc@santaclarapueblo.org) within 3 days of EPA submittal, and must provide the NOT within 3 days after EPA acceptance; additionally, any required PDMP must be emailed to the Environment Director when the NOI is submitted. These submissions ensure compliance with the Santa Clara Pueblo Water Quality Code and protection of tribal resources.

Lists the U.S. EPA mailing address and recipient details for submitting the Notice of Intent (NOI) for coverage under the Pesticide General Permit (PGP): Office of Water, Water Permits Division, Mail Code 4203M, ATTN: NPDES Pesticides, 1200 Pennsylvania Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20460. This is part of the instructions for completing and where to file the NOI for discharges from pesticide application.

Provides the overnight/express delivery address for submitting a Notice of Intent (NOI) to EPA’s NPDES Pesticides program and points users to online guidance and the NPDES eReporting help desk (phone and email). If filing a paper NOI, submit the original with an ink signature (no copies or faxes); include a Pesticide Discharge Management Plan (PDMP) with the NOI if one is required.

If you received approval to submit a paper (non-electronic) Notice of Termination for pesticide discharges under the PGP, mail it to: United States Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Water, Water Permits Division, Mail Code 4203M, ATTN: NPDES Pesticides, 1200 Pennsylvania Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20460.

Provides the overnight/express delivery address for filing a paper Notice of Termination to the EPA Office of Water (Water Permits Division, ATTN: NPDES Pesticides) and specifies that you must submit the original NOT with an ink signature—no copies or faxed submissions will be accepted.
section_summaries.Appendix G. Annual Report Template > **A: Gives the USPS mailing address for submitting the paper Annual Report (used when the electronic submission waiver is approved). Mail to: U.S. EPA, Office of Water, Water Permits Division, Mail Code 4203M, ATTN: NPDES Pesticides, 1200 Pennsylvania Avenue NW, Washington, DC 20460.

Provides the overnight/express delivery address for filing paper NPDES pesticide annual reports to the EPA Office of Water, and gives contact resources (website, NPDES eReporting help desk phone: 877-227-8965, email: NPDESeReporting@epa.gov). Instructs that paper annual reports must be the original with an ink signature and that copies or faxed submissions are not accepted.
section_summaries.Appendix G. Annual Report Template > App: Statement 1 requires confirming a prior ESA Section 7(a)(2) consultation fully covered direct and indirect effects of proposed pesticide discharges in the Project Action Area. The consultation must have resulted either in a biological opinion concluding no jeopardy/no adverse modification with Reasonable and Prudent Measures implemented, or a written concurrence that the discharges are not likely to adversely affect listed species or critical habitat (options to indicate FWS and/or NMFS).

This section documents Statement 2 for Criterion D eligibility, confirming an ESA Section 7(a)(2) consultation has concluded and fully covers discharge effects. It requires providing the geospatial map and list of FWS and NMFS Listed Resources of Concern, naming federal action agencies and Service field/regional offices, supplying consultation tracking numbers and completion dates, and attaching the consultation correspondence; if D1–D6 are met you may certify Criterion D on the NOI, otherwise proceed to Step 4.
section_summaries.9.0 Permit Conditions Applicable Within: Defines “surface waters of the state” and excludes certain private and treatment systems. Specifies tribe-specific Notice of Intent/Notice of Termination procedures: Ohkay Owingeh requires copies within three business days (contact/email provided); Isleta requires concurrent email and mail copies and electronic submissions for actions within 8 river miles; Sandia requires electronic NOI/NOT within three business days and a PDMP 10 days before pesticide application; Taos has no additional NOI requirements; Santa Clara requires NOI/NOT and any PDMP within three days. Table 1 footnotes explain criteria assumptions, carcinogen risk basis, adoption of new EPA criteria, site-specific adjustments, and pesticide/PCB sediment and tissue monitoring triggers.

This entry states that the Pueblo of Pojoaque has no additional Notice of Intent (NOI) requirements beyond the standard permit conditions. Users searching for local NOI obligations or guidance specific to this Pueblo can assume none are specified here.

Decision-makers covered by the PGP must send a certified NOI and any NOI modifications/NOT to the Pueblo of Picuris Governor and Environmental Department within two business days of EPA submittal (addresses provided), submit PDMPs electronically to environment@picurispueblo.org before or with the NOI, provide annual reports within three business days of EPA submittal, deliver DMRs concurrently with EPA submission, and notify the Picuris Pueblo Environmental Department within 10 days of any bypass or upset; these requirements allow the Tribe to review activities for compliance with its water quality standards.

Decision-makers must provide copies of NOIs, NOTs, PDMPs, and annual reports to the Pueblo of Santa Ana (contact: Tammy Montoya, Water Resources Division Manager) — generally electronically within three business days of EPA submittal or upon EPA acceptance for NOTs. Copies of all notifications, analytical data, and related correspondence for activities on Pueblo lands or within five river miles must be provided to the Pueblo simultaneously with EPA; the Pueblo may request additional information, delay or deny permits, and discharges are not authorized without an accurate, complete NOI.

Decision-makers required under Part 1.2 of the PGP must send a copy of their Notice of Intent (NOI) to the Pueblo of San Felipe Natural Resources Director within 3 days of EPA submittal and must provide the Notice of Termination (NOT) within 3 days of EPA acceptance (contact: pstout@sfpueblo.com). Those required under Part 5.0 must also submit an electronic copy of their Pesticide Discharge Management Plan (PDMP) to the same Tribal contact at the time the NOI is submitted. These requirements ensure compliance with water quality standards and protection of tribal resources.

This section lists the active ingredients approved for aquatic mosquito control under EPA Region 10 water quality permit conditions. The list includes bacterial larvicides (Bacillus sphaericus H-5a5b, Bacillus thuringiensis israelensis), chemical adulticides and larvicides (malathion, naled, pyrethrins, permethrin, prallethrin, resmethrin, sumithrin, deltamethrin, etofenprox), an insect growth regulator (methoprene), spinosad, a synergist (piperonyl butoxide), monomolecular surface films, and paraffinic white mineral oil.

Project proponents conducting mosquito control in EPA Region 10 (Washington) must avoid permanent harm to endangered, threatened, sensitive, or candidate species by following WDFW’s Areas of Restricted Larvicide and Adulticide Use map and complying with WDFW restrictions for areas within their jurisdiction.

Requirements for mosquito control in EPA Region 10 restrict where and how specific pesticides may be used: malathion is banned in lakes, streams, littoral zones and designated vulnerable‑species areas (allowed only for larval resistance after WDFW consultation), methoprene briquettes are prohibited in marine/estuarine sites, and malathion and naled are barred in vulnerable‑species areas. Adulticides should be applied with ultra‑low volume (ULV) equipment when available. The section provides WDFW contact information and cites Washington water‑quality and wildlife laws as the legal justification.

Specifies authorized herbicide application limits in littoral zones by waterbody size (≤15 acres: 75%; >15–50 acres: 60%; >50–500 acres: 50%; >500 acres: 30%), requires the same geographic treatment area for the permit duration, and mandates that untreated littoral areas retain native vegetation from shore to the growth limit. Allows 100% treatment of plants within rights-of-way, levees, and dikes; caps treatment of native vegetation on shorelines/roadsides/ditches at 40% (but 100% for noxious or quarantine-listed weeds). Notes that discharge permits can restrict where chemicals are applied but cannot control dispersion beyond environmental variability.

Project proponents may apply algaecides to filamentous green algae (within littoral-zone limits) and may treat entire waterbodies for cyanobacteria or toxic algae, but must follow restrictions including pre- and post-treatment dissolved oxygen monitoring (post-treatment DO must not drop more than 0.2 mg/L below pre-treatment levels). If a full-waterbody treatment risks lethal DO drops or pre-treatment monitoring is infeasible, alternatives allowed are phosphorus sequestration products or phased treatment of up to one-third of the lake per week. The conditions implement AKART and cite Washington statutes and WAC chapters.

Project proponents must consult WDFW Fish Program staff before conducting rotenone fish treatments and must follow the latest "Planning and Standard Operating Procedures for Use of Rotenone in Fish Management" (Rotenone SOP Manual). The conditions restrict allowable active ingredients and application methods to meet AKART and state water quality standards; see section 8 for water rights and replacement water requirements. Relevant statutory and regulatory citations (RCW and WAC) are listed for compliance reference.

If the default WDFW timing window will not allow adequate treatment, applicants must contact the regional WDFW biologist (see the Areas of Responsibilities Map Tool) to develop a modified timing window. WDFW timing windows apply to specific pesticides (2,4‑D amine/ester, carfentrazone‑ethyl, approved chelated copper compounds, chlorine, diquat, endothall dipotassium/mono salts, flumioxazin, potassium permanganate, and rotenone); for irrigation canals the timing window requirement only applies to endothall mono salt. Ecology must follow WDFW mandates to protect sensitive species (see RCW 77.15.120; 77.15.130(1); 77.04.012 and WDFW Priority Habitat and Species/AkART references).

Explains how to file an appeal with the PCHB — for current filing procedures visit https://eluho.wa.gov/ or call (360) 664-9160 — and provides the service address for Ecology: Department of Ecology, Attn: Appeals Processing Desk, 300 Desmond Drive SE, Lacey, WA 98503.

Provides the mailing and email contact for submitting appeals under “Your right to appeal” for EPA Region 10: Department of Ecology, Attn: Appeals Processing Desk, PO Box 47608, Olympia, WA 98504-7608, and email ecologyappeals@ecy.wa.gov.

This subsection of the Certification block on the NOI form captures the preparer’s contact details to be filled out only if the Notice of Intent was prepared by someone other than the certifier. Fields include preparer name, organization, phone number and extension, date, and email address.

Operators meeting permit eligibility (Parts 1.1 and 1.2.2) must file a Notice of Intent (NOI) when Decision-makers have covered discharges, including any discharges overlapping FWS/NMFS listed resources or to Tier 3 (Outstanding National Resource) waters (see Table 1‑1 and Part 1.1.2.4). Local governments or entities that treat more than 6,400 acres in a calendar year also must submit an NOI; a single NOI may cover multiple pest management areas but only within one state. See Appendix I for required NOI information and ESA eligibility criteria.

Do not file an NOI until you have read the PGP, completed the ESA eligibility worksheet and PDMP (unless exempt for a Declared Pest Emergency or certain Decision-makers), and are prepared to certify accuracy. Paper NOI use requires EPA Regional Office approval. NOIs submitted under the 2021 PGP terminate 10/30/2026; for discharges after 10/31/2026 decision-makers must submit a new NOI under the 2026 PGP. For new treatment areas that may expose listed resources, submit at least 30 days before discharge (or notify within 15 days/coordinate with FWS/NMFS for Declared Pest Emergencies), and coverage is generally effective no earlier than 30 days after EPA posts receipt unless an emergency applies.

Decision-makers must submit the NOI through EPA’s NPDES eReporting Tool (NeT) unless granted an electronic submission waiver (see Part 8 for Regional contacts and waiver form). EPA posts all NOIs immediately; late NOIs are accepted but coverage won’t be retroactive. If waived from NeT, mail the original paper NOI with an ink signature to EPA (addresses provided for U.S. Mail and overnight/express delivery) and include a Pesticide Discharge Management Plan (PDMP) if required; guidance and eReporting help desk contact information are available online.

Provides brief instructions for completing the Notice of Intent (NOI) for PGP coverage: type or print in uppercase, answer all questions, make a photocopy for your records, and mail the completed original to the listed address. The paper form can also be used as a checklist when filing the NOI electronically via EPA's NPDES eReporting Tool (NeT).

This section asks whether the Notice of Intent (NOI) is a first-time request or a change to an existing NOI. First-time applicants are directed to Table 1-2 for submission deadlines and authorization dates; those reporting a change must provide the NPDES permit tracking number from EPA’s NeT, consult Table 1-3 for guidance, and update Section B (operator name and mailing address) and any other modified fields.

Instructions require the legal name of the Decision-maker (operator with control over pesticide applications), the operator type (and optional six-digit NAICS), whether the operator is a “large entity” (which triggers a required Pesticide Discharge Management Plan and annual reporting), the single state where pest management occurs (one state per NOI), and full contact/mailing details for correspondence.

Instructions for completing Section C of the NOI require one Section C per pest management area and collection of the area name plus geospatial mapping data (decimal degrees, WGS84) or map via EPA’s mapping tool. The form also asks whether applications occur on Indian Country or Federal facilities, contact/mailing details, pesticide use patterns, and whether coverage is requested for all U.S. waters or specific Tier 3 or impaired waters — with required written justification and impairment verification attachments.

Applicants must demonstrate eligibility under one or more ESA criteria (A–G) showing pesticide discharges are not likely to adversely affect federally listed species or critical habitat for the entire permit term, and provide supporting documentation (see Appendix I worksheet). Required submittals include a geospatial map of the Project Action Area using EPA’s mapping tool and a species/habitat overlap list generated within 90 days; paper NOIs must include these maps/lists. If using Criteria F or G, supply detailed pesticide, application method, timing, quantities, and rationale showing “not likely to adversely affect”; for Declared Pest Emergencies, coordination and email notification to FWS/NMFS/EPA is required. For discharges under Criteria C, D, or E, EPA may authorize in less than 30 days (no fewer than 10); if no EPA response within 30 days after certification, you may assume authorization.

Section E requires applicants to indicate which supporting documents they are submitting with their Notice of Intent (NOI), using the listed attachment options. If submitting a document not on the list, select “Other” and provide a brief description of that attachment.

This section explains the NOI certification: the certifier must print name, title, sign and date (unsigned/undated forms are not accepted) and is subject to penalties for false information. It details who may sign (corporate officers or authorized managers meeting specific authority criteria; general partners or proprietors; principal executives or ranking elected officials for public entities), references 40 CFR 122.41(k), and requires contact info for the preparer if someone else completed the NOI.

States that the Paperwork Reduction Act estimates a 2.5-hour (150-minute) public reporting/recordkeeping burden per NOI response and invites comments on the need for the information, accuracy of the burden estimate, and ways to reduce respondent burden (including automation). Directs comments to the Director, Collection Strategies Division, U.S. EPA (2822T), 1200 Pennsylvania Ave., NW, Washington, D.C. 20460, instructing respondents to include the OMB control number and not to send completed NOI forms to that address.

Operators who were required to submit a Notice of Intent (NOI) must file a Notice of Termination (NOT) to end PGP coverage, except when EPA directs them to seek an individual or alternative general permit (coverage then terminates automatically) or when dischargers automatically covered stop discharging per permit criteria. NOIs under the 2021 PGP automatically terminate at 11:59 p.m. on October 30, 2026; Decision-makers who need continued coverage must submit a new NOI for the 2026 PGP. For questions, see https://www.epa.gov/npdes/pesticide-permitting or contact the NPDES eReporting help desk.

Operators must file the NOT within 30 days after one or more conditions in Part 1.2.5.2 of the permit are met. Use of the paper NOT form requires an EPA Regional Office waiver—if approved, record the waiver type, the EPA staff person who granted it, and the approval date.

Operators must submit the Notice of Termination (NOT) through EPA’s NPDES eReporting Tool (NeT) unless granted an Electronic Submission Waiver. If a waiver is approved, mail the paper NOT to the EPA Office of Water (Water Permits Division) at the provided U.S. mail or overnight/express delivery addresses and include the original NOT with an ink signature; see Part 8 of the PGP for EPA Regional contacts.

Instructions require typing or printing in uppercase, answering all questions, making a photocopy for your records, and sending the original to the listed address; the paper form can also be used as a checklist when filing the Notice of Termination electronically via EPA’s NPDES eReporting Tool (NeT).

Section A instructs the submitter to provide the existing NPDES Permit Tracking Number (retrievable via EPA's NeT) and to select one of three NOT reasons: (a) ceased all pesticide discharges, (b) obtained individual/alternative NPDES permit coverage, or (c) transferred operator responsibility — if (c), include the transfer date and new operator’s name and contact information.

Section B requires the Operator’s full legal name (the decision-maker), the Operator’s mailing address and telephone for correspondence, and a contact person’s full legal name and e‑mail address for any Notice of Termination (NOT) communications under the Pesticide General Permit.

Operators must certify they no longer discharge pesticides to U.S. waters by providing printed full legal name, title, email, and signing and dating the NOT (an unsigned/undated form prevents termination). The form explains authorized signatories by entity type (corporate officers or qualified managers for corporations; general partner/proprietor for partnerships/sole proprietorships; principal executive or ranking elected official for public entities). Federal penalties apply for false information, and if the NOT was prepared by someone else, that preparer's name, organization, phone and email must be included.

States the Paperwork Reduction Act estimate of 0.5 hours (30 minutes) per NOT response and directs comments on the need for the information, burden estimates, or methods to minimize burden to the Director, Collection Strategies Division, U.S. EPA (2822T) at 1200 Pennsylvania Ave., NW, Washington, D.C. 20460, noting the OMB control number must be included. It explicitly instructs not to send the completed NOT form to that address; applies to the Approval to Use Paper (electronic submission waiver) instructions for the PGP NOT.

Small-entity Operators who are Decision-makers required to submit a Notice of Intent (NOI) under Part 7.3 may use this Pesticide Discharge Evaluation Worksheet (PDEW). The section clarifies that a pest management area (per Appendix A) can span large or small areas and may include multiple treatment areas—Operators must retain a worksheet for each treatment area, though one worksheet may document multiple similar treatment areas.

Operators covered by the PGP must complete Section B of the PDEW before any pesticide application. Section C (except the application end date and total quantity) must be finished as soon as possible but no later than 14 days after the first application; the end date and total quantity must be entered as soon as possible but no later than 14 days after the project’s pesticide application is complete. Operators must retain the worksheet for at least 3 years from coverage date or permit expiration/termination and make it available to EPA upon request.

This section provides instructions for completing the Pesticide Discharge Evaluation Worksheet (PDEW) for the Pesticide General Permit (PGP) covering discharges from pesticide applications. It emphasizes filling the form in uppercase and ensuring all questions and appropriate areas are fully completed to document pesticide discharge evaluations.

Section A (General Information) of the PDEW collects identifying and locational data for each pest management area, including the operator’s legal name and NPDES tracking number, the person completing the form, pest management area numbering and name, pesticide use pattern(s), and brief descriptions and locations of each treatment area with size (acres or linear feet) and any U.S. waters receiving discharges.

Section B (Pest Evaluation) of the PDEW directs users to identify target pest(s) and explain why control is needed, and to describe any pest management measures used prior to pesticide application. It emphasizes documenting non-chemical/physical control actions (e.g., pulling weeds, removing breeding habitat, trapping animals) as part of the permit evaluation.

Section C instructs users to record applicator name and contact, application start/end dates, each pesticide product used with EPA registration number, quantity applied, and application method. It also requires documentation of whether visual monitoring occurred (including date/time/location or reason it was not done) and a brief description of any adverse effects observed during monitoring.

Requires the certifier’s printed name, title, signature and date (unsigned/undated forms are invalid), cites 40 CFR 122.41(k), and warns of penalties for false information. Specifies who may sign on behalf of different entity types (responsible corporate officer or authorized manager for corporations; general partner/proprietor for partnerships/sole proprietorships; principal executive or ranking elected official for public facilities) and mandates contact details if a preparer other than the certifier completed the PDEW.

This notice states the Paperwork Reduction Act burden for the Pesticide Discharge Evaluation Worksheet is estimated at 1 hour per response. It directs comments about the need for the information, burden accuracy, or methods to reduce burden (including automation) to the Director, Collection Strategies Division, U.S. EPA (2822T), 1200 Pennsylvania Ave., NW, Washington, D.C. 20460, and instructs respondents to include the OMB control number and not to send completed PDEWs to that address.
section_summaries.Appendix G. Annual Report Template > **A: Any Operator who is a Decision-maker required to submit an NOI and is a large entity, or whose application results in discharge to U.S. waters or may expose FWS/NMFS Listed Resources of Concern to pollutants, must submit an annual report to EPA each calendar year. Once an operator is required to file for one year, they must continue filing every subsequent year of the permit regardless of whether discharges occur (see Parts 7.6 and 7.7 of the PGP).

Operators must submit annual reports by February 15 for pesticide activities in the prior calendar year. If an NOI was required because an annual treatment-area threshold was exceeded, the first report must cover activity after the exceedance (unless the exceedance occurred after Dec 1, in which case the first partial year need not be reported); if permit coverage is terminated, submit a report for activities up to the termination date, due the following Feb 15.

Annual Reports must be filed via EPA’s NPDES eReporting Tool (NetT) unless an electronic submission waiver is granted; if waived, submit a paper report to the EPA Office of Water using the provided USPS or overnight/express addresses. Paper reports must be original with an ink signature (no copies or faxes accepted); contact the NPDES eReporting helpdesk (877-227-8965, NPDESeReporting@epa.gov) or the EPA NPDES pesticide permitting webpage for guidance.

Enter the permit tracking number from your NOI (findable via EPA’s NPDES eReporting Tool/NetT). Provide the legal name of the Decision‑maker (operator with control over pesticide application decisions), the Operator’s address/telephone/fax, and the Annual Report contact person’s full legal name, title, and email.

Section B requires reporting any adverse incidents and corrective actions for each covered pest management area: enter the pest area name, dates of incidents (use extra pages for multiple dates), and the date/time/person/instructions when the Operator notified EPA per Part 6.4.1.1. Also record the date the 30-day Adverse Incident Written Report was submitted and provide descriptions and rationale for corrective actions performed subsequently or in addition to those in the 30-day report.

Section C is completed for each pest management area (must match the NOI) and records whether discharges from pest control activities occurred, the pesticide use pattern, and a detailed treatment-area description including a geospatial map, area size, receiving waters, and target pests. It also captures if discharges may affect FWS/NMFS Listed Resources (with dates), whether visual monitoring was conducted during and after application (attach records or explain), applicator contact details (or same as Section A), whether the activity was in the PDMP, and the total amount applied.

The certifier must print their name and title, sign and date the form (unsigned/undated forms are not accepted), and the signature must be by an authorized individual per 40 CFR 122.41(k)—specified officers for corporations (or an authorized manager meeting stated authority criteria), a general partner or proprietor for partnerships/sole proprietorships, and a principal executive or ranking elected official for public facilities. Federal penalties apply for false information. If someone else prepared the Annual Report, include the preparer’s name, organization, phone, and email.

This Paperwork Reduction Act notice states that the public reporting and recordkeeping burden for the annual report form (electronic submission waiver) is estimated at an average of 8 hours (480 minutes) per response. The section is labeled as part of the EPA appendix and includes the EPA logo.
section_summaries.Appendix G. Annual Report Template > UNI: Captures the caller’s contact details for the 24-hour adverse incident notification under the PGP—specifically the reporter’s name and telephone number (with extension). Used in the 30-day adverse incident written report (Appendix G) to identify and enable follow-up with the person who made the notification.

Collects operator identification and contact details from the 24-hour adverse incident notification: operator name and full mailing address (street, city, state, ZIP). Also requests the NOI/NPDES Permit Tracking Number, with instruction to enter 'NA' if not applicable.

Fields for providing an alternate contact person (if different from the initial 24-hour notifier) including name and telephone number with extension, as part of the 24-hour adverse incident notification section of the PGP 30-day written report.

This field asks the Operator to describe how and when they became aware of the adverse incident—specifying the detection method (e.g., routine monitoring, observation, third‑party complaint), the date and time, and who observed or reported it. Include details on who was notified internally and any initial notifications to authorities or other parties and the timeline of those notifications.

This section of the 30‑day PGP adverse incident report collects the incident location, a description of the adverse incident and each pesticide product applied (including EPA registration numbers), actions taken or planned to remedy/clean up impacts, and identification/notification details for any other Operators covered under the permit.

All Operators who observe or become aware of a reportable adverse incident under Part 6.4 must submit a 30-day written report; EPA recommends documenting even incidents not required to be reported to preserve rationale. An adverse incident is evidence that a person or non-target organism was likely exposed to a pesticide residue and suffered a toxic or adverse effect (see Appendix A). If multiple Operators are authorized, submission by any one Operator satisfies the requirement provided copies of the report are given to the other authorized Operators within 30 days.

Operators must submit a written report of any reportable adverse incidents under the PGP to the appropriate EPA Regional office and the state lead pesticide agency within 30 days, as required by Part 6.4.1.1 of the permit.

Operators must notify the EPA Incident Reporting Contact within 24 hours of an adverse incident and submit a written 30‑day adverse incident report to the appropriate EPA Regional office (address in Part 8) and the state lead pesticide agency. If the incident may have affected federally listed threatened or endangered species or critical habitat, operators must immediately notify NMFS for anadromous/marine species or the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service for terrestrial/freshwater species; contact links are provided in the permit guidance.

Operators must indicate whether an adverse incident is reportable on the 30-day PGP form; if not reportable, no further action is required. Reporting is not required when the incident is unrelated to pesticide toxic effects/exposure, when EPA has waived reporting, when the notification is clearly erroneous, or when effects are limited to pests similar to labeled targets—except as specified in Part 6.4.3 regarding threatened or endangered species or critical habitat.

Section B requires entering the caller and Operator contact details (including an alternative contact), the NOI/NPDES tracking number from NeT (or “NA” if none), and descriptions of how and when the Operator became aware of the adverse incident, where it occurred, and what happened (including non‑target organisms and signs of effects). It also requires listing pesticide products and EPA registration numbers used in the incident, documenting corrective/cleanup measures taken, and identifying/confirming notification of any other Operators covered by the permit.

Record when EPA was contacted about the adverse incident (date and time), the legal name and title of the EPA staff member contacted, and a brief description of any instructions or guidance provided by EPA for the 30‑day PGP adverse incident report.

Section D lists the specific information required in the 30-day adverse-incident report: precise incident location and water appearance; description of affected species, signs, estimated numbers and sizes; magnitude/area of impact; pesticide product name, EPA registration number, application rate, site and method; habitat and ambient water data; any laboratory tests and timing of results; and actions planned to prevent recurrence.

Requires the certifier to print name/title, sign and date the 30‑day adverse incident report (unsigned/undated forms are not accepted) and cites 40 CFR 122.41(k). Specifies who may sign: a responsible corporate officer or authorized manager for corporations, a general partner or proprietor for partnerships/sole proprietorships, and a principal executive or ranking elected official for public entities. If a consultant or other person prepared the report, include the preparer’s name, organization, phone, email, and preparation date; warns of severe penalties for falsification.

Notifies respondents that the estimated public reporting burden for the 30‑day Adverse Incident Report is 4 hours (240 minutes) per response and solicits comments on the need, accuracy, and ways to minimize burden (including automated collection). Directs comments to the Director, Collection Strategies Division, U.S. EPA (2822T), 1200 Pennsylvania Ave., NW, Washington, DC 20460, instructs to include the OMB control number, and clarifies that completed reports should not be sent to that address.
section_summaries.Appendix G. Annual Report Template > App: To meet ESA Criterion A you must use EPA's geospatial mapping tool (output within 90 days) to confirm whether FWS and/or NMFS Listed Resources of Concern are directly or indirectly within the Project Action Area; if resources are present proceed to Step 3 (or Step 6 for a Declared Pest Emergency). If no listed resources are found, certify Criterion A and submit the map/list with your NOI only if you are required to file one (paper NOI waivers must include the map, list, and worksheet).
Criterion B for ESA eligibility contains no requirements in this worksheet and is intentionally left blank. Users should skip this section and proceed directly to Step 3.

Describes eligibility for Criterion C if you already hold an ESA Section 10(a)(1) permit that fully covers the effects of your proposed discharges and discharge-related activities on all FWS and/or NMFS Listed Resources of Concern in your Project Action Area (as confirmed using the Step 1 geospatial mapping tool). Requires providing which Service issued the permit, field/regional office, permit/tracking numbers, permit date, and attaching correspondence and the permit or tracking info to the NOI; if you cannot supply C1–C6, proceed to Criterion D.

Criterion D allows certification only if a prior ESA Section 7(a)(2) consultation fully addressed the direct and indirect effects of the proposed discharges and resulted in written concurrence or a biological opinion finding no jeopardy/no adverse modification. To claim Criterion D you must have completed Step 1, attest Statements 1 and 2, and provide supporting information D1–D6 (geospatial map and resource list, agency/Service contacts, consultation tracking numbers, dates, and correspondence). Reinitiation of consultation under 50 C.F.R. §402.16 makes you ineligible while pending.

Requires completed coordination with the appropriate Service(s) (FWS and/or NMFS) and written confirmation—obtained prior to NOI submission—that planned discharges and related activities are not likely to cause short- or long-term adverse effects to listed species; applicants must provide the EPA geospatial map and species list used, identify which Service(s) and office(s) participated, record coordination dates, and agree to comply with any required measures/conditions.

Criterion F allows PGP coverage if you self-certify and document that discharges and discharge-related activities are not likely to cause short- or long-term adverse effects to each FWS/NMFS listed species or designated critical habitat in the Project Action Area. You must identify and implement specific avoidance measures/BMPs (e.g., timing, avoidance, lower concentrations, monitoring), describe them in the NOI, include responses to F1–F7 and mapping outputs, and contact the appropriate Service or EPA (pgp@epa.gov) if you need help; inability to answer F1–F7 makes you ineligible under Criterion F.

Criterion G allows pesticide discharges in response to a Declared Pest Emergency if Decision-makers promptly notify and coordinate with FWS and/or NMFS, implement any Service technical recommendations, and provide documentation and written confirmation with the NOI. An NOI must be filed within 15 days of discharge start (30 days if no listed resources occur in the Project Action Area), include a Project Action Area map and listed-resources report, and include responses to G1–G7 to certify eligibility; changes to proposed discharges require restarting coordination. If the application is not a Declared Pest Emergency, proceed to Step 1 to reassess eligibility.
section_summaries.Appendices > 1.1 Eligibility > 1.1.2 Lim: Operators are not eligible for permit coverage for pesticide discharges to U.S. waters that are listed as impaired for an active ingredient or its degradate. "Impaired waters" are those identified under CWA Section 303(d), including waters with or without EPA-approved/established TMDLs (list at https://www.epa.gov/tmdl/). Operators may submit evidence per Table 1-2 in Part 1.2.3 to request coverage if the water is no longer impaired.

Operators are not eligible for permit coverage for discharges to waters designated Tier 3 (Outstanding National Resource Waters) under 40 CFR 131.12(a)(3), except for limited pesticide application cases. The narrow exception applies only to pesticide uses that restore or maintain water quality or protect public health/environment and that either do not degrade water quality or cause only short-term/temporary degradation; a list of Tier 3 waters is on EPA’s NPDES pesticide permitting webpage.

A discharge is ineligible for this permit if it is currently covered by another NPDES permit or if it was included in a permit that has been or is being denied, terminated, or revoked by EPA within the past five years (excluding routine five‑year reissuance).

Permit coverage applies only to discharges that meet one of the ESA eligibility criteria (A–G) and requires use of EPA’s geospatial mapping tool to identify any FWS/NMFS Listed Resources of Concern in the Project Action Area. Activities meeting A–G are generally not expected to adversely affect listed species or critical habitat, except where effects have been addressed under Criteria C or D (Section 10/Section 7 consultations) or temporarily under Criterion G; Criterion G requires NOI supporting documentation including an email notification to FWS/NMFS/EPA, a project description, geospatial map, and a list (or absence) of Listed Resources of Concern (see Appendices D and I).
section_summaries.6.0 Corrective Action > 6.4 Adverse Inci: Operators must telephone the EPA Incident Reporting Contact within 24 hours of becoming aware of any adverse incident possibly resulting from a pesticide discharge and provide specified details (caller info, operator name/address, NOI NPDES permit tracking number if applicable, alternate contact, how/when discovered, location, incident description including affected non-target organisms and pesticide registration numbers, actions taken, and identities of other covered operators). If unable to notify within 24 hours, Operators must notify as soon as possible and explain the delay; these requirements are in addition to registrant obligations under FIFRA Section 6(a)(2).

This section lists four situations where 24-hour adverse-incident reporting is not required: the incident is not related to toxic effects from the pesticide application; EPA has waived reporting for the incident or category; the received information is clearly erroneous; or the incident affects pests similar to labeled target pests (with a cross-reference that incidents involving threatened or endangered species/critical habitat are covered under Part 6.4.3).
section_summaries.9.0 Permit Conditions Applicable Within: Operators must file a MassDEP WM04 application and obtain approval before applying chemicals for weed and algae control in Massachusetts (with limited agency and private-pond exemptions). Specific conditions for alum treatments prohibit causing fish kills, require maintaining pond pH between 6.5–8.3 with multi-point pH profiling (surface, bottom, and intermediate points), and mandate aluminum testing if pH remains outside range. Observed dead/dying aquatic life or pH excursions must be reported to the Massachusetts Environmental Police and MassDEP, and full monitoring data and a treatment narrative must be included in the report.

For mosquito and other flying insect pest control in Massachusetts (excluding Indian Country), chemical treatments must be performed by applicators licensed/certified by the MDAR Pesticide Program and comply with M.G.L. c.132B, c.252, 333 CMR 10.00 and 14.00, and any State Reclamation and Mosquito Control Board policies; operators must also follow applicable public notification requirements under the Child Protection Act (Chapter 85 of the Acts of 2000).

Antidegradation reviews are carried out based on the waterbody’s protection tier, type, existing baseline quality, projected impacts, and the nature of the proposed discharge. The requirements apply to regulated discharges that could degrade water quality, including NPDES point-source discharges (Section 402), discharges placing dredged/fill material (Section 404), and discharges under federal permits/licenses that require state Section 401 certification.

General NPDES permits are not subject to a Tier 2 antidegradation review, but new and reissued general permits must be evaluated for potential significant degradation. The review focuses on whether permit conditions are met and BMPs are effective at minimizing pollutant loadings, with EPA Region 6’s NMIP providing implementation guidance.

This section explains the NMWQS Antidegradation Policy and Implementation Plan, which requires protection of designated uses and existing water quality that exceeds those uses. It states that permit limits and monitoring must be designed to meet State water quality standards and protect the receiving water’s assimilative capacity, ensuring permits do not degrade protected uses.

Explains that antidegradation review is determined by the receiving water’s protection tier, water type, baseline quality, projected impacts, and discharge characteristics, and applies to discharges that could degrade water quality — including NPDES point sources (CWA §402), dredged/fill activities (CWA §404), and any federal-permitted discharges requiring state CWA §401 certification.

General NPDES permits in New Mexico are not subject to a full Tier 2 antidegradation review, but new and reissued general permits must be evaluated for potential significant degradation. The determination focuses on whether permit conditions are met and whether required BMPs effectively limit pollutant loading, since covered activities are considered socially and economically important. EPA Region 6’s NMIP provides the implementing procedures for this evaluation.

The section explains that New Mexico’s Antidegradation Policy and Implementation Plan requires permits (including general NPDES permits) to protect designated uses and existing water quality that exceeds those uses. Permit limits and monitoring must be set to protect state water quality standards and the assimilative capacity of receiving waters.

Applicators must be licensed in Washington to apply aquatically labeled pesticides and must comply with Washington laws and regulations (WAC 16-228, RCW 15.58, RCW 17.21). This condition ensures pesticides are applied legally and appropriately in EPA Region 10.

Pesticide applications in Washington (EPA Region 10) must not cause or contribute to violations of state surface water, groundwater, and sediment standards or the human-health criteria in the National Toxics Rule (40 CFR 131.36); non-complying discharges are prohibited. The requirement is justified to protect aquatic life, habitats, and human health.

Washington allows short-term exceedances of water quality criteria for pesticide and chemical treatments if the project proponent complies with WAC 173-201A-410, and compliance is satisfied by following the Pesticide General Permit. All pesticide discharges to or entering surface waters must submit an NOI and obtain coverage under the 2026 Pesticide General Permit to meet state antidegradation and pollution control requirements (WAC 173-201A-300; RCW 90.48.080, 90.48.520).

Lists approved active ingredients for aquatic mosquito control in Washington (bacterial larvicides, chemical larvicides/adulticides, IGRs, spinosad, synergists, monomolecular films, mineral oil) and specifies use conditions and site prohibitions—including protections for endangered/threatened/sensitive/candidate species, bans or limits on malathion, naled, and methoprene in certain waters, and requirement to consult WDFW and use ULV adulticide application when available. Includes WDFW contact info and cites Washington water‑quality and wildlife laws as authority.

Lists approved pesticides and products for freshwater aquatic plant and algae management in EPA Region 10 (including herbicides, algaecides, nutrient inactivation agents, marker dyes, and water clarification products) and directs users to WSDA for adjuvant approvals. Sets littoral-zone treatment caps by waterbody size (≤15 ac 75%; >15–50 ac 60%; >50–500 ac 50%; >500 ac 30%), requires retention of untreated native vegetation near shore, allows full-waterbody treatment for cyanobacteria with strict pre/post dissolved-oxygen monitoring (post-treatment DO must not drop >0.2 mg/L) or alternatives (phosphorus sequestration or phased one-third/week treatments), and restricts water clarification products in bodies that discharge to other surface waters during and for two weeks after treatment.

Authorizes shoreline and emergent noxious weed herbicide applications in freshwater and marine sites (when pesticides are not directly discharged to water) only for state-listed noxious weeds and WSDA quarantine species, and lists approved active ingredients (e.g., aminopyralid, glyphosate, triclopyr TEA, imazapyr, etc.), plus adjuvants and marker dyes (contact WSDA pestreg@agr.wa.gov or (360) 902-2030 for approved adjuvants). Includes AKART justification and cites Washington RCW and WAC provisions governing water quality and pesticide use.

Limits Zostera japonica control to commercial clam beds in Willapa Bay with one imazamox application per year (April 15–June 30); prohibits adjuvants, treatment of geoduck beds, and direct application into drainage containing Z. marina moving offsite. Requires a 10-meter buffer inside parcel boundaries unless adjacent commercial shellfish owners agree to waive it; restrictions justified under AKART and multiple Washington statutes and WAC citations.

Conditions for irrigation-system aquatic weed control in Washington specify approved active ingredients (e.g., dissolved copper, acrolein, endothall salts, xylene, fluridone, imazapyr, sodium carbonate peroxyhydrate) and require adjuvant approval from WSDA. The Project proponent must ensure pesticide concentrations at the point of compliance do not exceed listed maximum instantaneous limits (e.g., dissolved copper 25 µg/L, acrolein 21 µg/L, dipotassium endothall 5.0 mg/L, mono-endothall 0.050 mg/L with timing windows, xylene 5.1 mg/L). Requirements are justified as AKART and cite relevant Washington statutes and WACs.

EPA Region 10 (Washington) permit conditions allow marine and freshwater projects to control non‑native invasive animals and algae only for species listed in Washington Administrative Code (WAC), the Washington Invasive Species Council (WISC) priority list, USFWS Lacey Act listings, WA quarantine pests, or species otherwise approved in consultation with WDFW/WDNR/WSDA or federal agencies. Approved control agents include salts (sodium/potassium chloride), chlorine compounds, acetic acid, lime/carbon dioxide for marine/freshwater use, plus freshwater‑only agents such as endothall, sodium carbonate peroxyhydrate, methoprene, chelated copper, and Pseudomonas fluorescens strain CL145A; project proponents must consult WDFW Aquatic Invasive Species staff prior to treatment.

Washington-specific conditions for rotenone fish management: only state-registered rotenone products are allowed and potassium permanganate (KMnO4) is the approved chemical to deactivate treated waters. Project proponents must consult WDFW Fish Program staff, follow the latest Rotenone SOP Manual, and ensure application methods and active ingredients meet AKART and state water quality and water-rights/replacement requirements (see section 8), with relevant RCW/WAC references provided.

Washington State limits invasive insect control treatments to specific approved agents (Bacillus thuringiensis var. kurstaki, pheromones like disparlure, chlorantraniliprole, cyfluthrin, imidacloprid, Japanese beetle nematode) and requires adjuvants be registered/approved in WA. Treatments must allow a three-day interval before retreatment, project proponents must notify WDFW about state-listed threatened/endangered/candidate species 60 days before treatment, and further details and permit requirements are in the Invasive Moth Control Permit and state water quality/AKART regulations cited.

In Washington State, forest canopy pest control projects must follow Title 76 RCW and specific restrictions on active ingredients, timing, and application methods to protect aquatic life, sensitive or threatened species, and meet water quality standards by implementing AKART (all known, available, and reasonable methods of prevention, control and treatment).

Project proponents must publish a newspaper public notice before the first seasonal pesticide application listing the treatment schedule, common name of the water body, pesticides/chemicals to be used, any water-use restrictions, contact information (including Ecology’s 24-hour emergency number), and an explanation that treated areas will be posted no more than 48 hours before treatment to protect public health and water use.

Requires project proponents in EPA Region 10 to post shoreline treatment notices using Ecology permit templates (links provided for aquatic invasive species, mosquito control, noxious weed control, and plant/algae management). Signs must be placed at reasonable public access points and, where feasible, extend 400 feet beyond treatment boundaries, be posted no more than 48 hours before treatment, include commonly spoken local languages, and be removed after water-use restrictions end; cites RCW 90.48.010 and WAC 173-226-130.

Ecology requires project proponents to notify all potable, irrigation, or livestock water users with valid water rights or claims (and those within product label setback distances) before chemical treatments and annually when treatments occur; water-rights info is available on Ecology’s website. If requested, proponents must provide at least two weeks’ advance notice and, at their own expense, supply an alternative/replacement water source until the withdrawn water tests at or below the active ingredient concentration specified on the product label, with provision details agreed with the affected user.

Project proponents must consult and comply with Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW) waterbody-specific timing windows (map and contact provided) before aquatic pesticide treatments to protect sensitive and listed species; some windows require prior WDFW consultation and apply to specified pesticides (and endothall mono salt for irrigation canals). Exceptions include treatments for emergent/shoreline plants, roadside/ditch/flood-control vegetation, and nonnative fish (though proponents may opt to follow nonnative-fish windows). Ecology must adhere to WDFW mandates and statutory protections.

Before applying herbicides or algaecides, project proponents must consult the WA DNR Natural Heritage Program and check the rare-plant map, survey the site if a rare plant is reported, and implement mitigations in coordination with DNR staff prior to treatment. Contact details (phone, email, website) and RCW 79.70 citations are provided for compliance and consultation.

You have 30 days from receipt to appeal this Order to the Pollution Control Hearings Board (PCHB) under Chapter 43.21B RCW and Chapter 371-08 WAC; “filing” requires actual receipt by the PCHB. To appeal, file a notice of appeal and a copy of the Order with the PCHB and serve a copy on the Department of Ecology (Attn: Appeals Processing Desk); see current filing procedures at https://eluho.wa.gov/ or (360) 664-9160. Ecology contact: Department of Ecology, Attn: Appeals Processing Desk, PO Box 47608, Olympia, WA 98504-7608; email ecologyappeals@ecy.wa.gov.

Provides the designated contact for questions about this Order under EPA Region 10 notification requirements: Danielle Edelman, Department of Ecology, with mailing address (P.O. Box 47600, Olympia, WA 98503-7600), phone (360-407-7118), and email (danielle.edelman@ecy.wa.gov).

Provides links to Washington State authorities and statutes relevant to EPA Region 10 permit notifications and appeals, including the Pollution Control Hearings Board website, RCW chapters on administrative procedure and water pollution control, and WAC chapters on practice/procedure, sediment management, and ground/surface water quality standards.

This section lists EPA Region 10 notification/permit conditions for Indian Country in Washington: most tribes (e.g., Chehalis, Colville, Kalispel, Puyallup, Quinault, Spokane, Squaxin, Swinomish, Tulalip) have no additional requirements, while the Lummi Tribe requires land-use permits, adherence to Lummi water quality standards, immediate pesticide spill notification, and NOI submission; the Makah Tribe requires advance reporting (7 business days, preferably 30), and Jamestown S'Klallam requires immediate cessation and coordination if covered pesticide applications cause impacts.

Lists EPA Region 1 permit condition identifiers and the specific areas where EPA is the permitting authority — covering Massachusetts (MAG87####), Indian Country within Connecticut (CTG87####E) and Rhode Island (RIG87####E), New Hampshire (NHG87####), federal facilities in Vermont (VTG87####E), all other Indian Country not otherwise listed (01G87####E), and lands of exclusive federal jurisdiction (01G87####).

Enumerates areas in EPA Region 2 where EPA is the permitting authority, including Indian Country within New York (NYG87####E), Puerto Rico (PRG87####), other Indian Country not covered by an EPA‑approved permitting program (02G87####E), and all lands of exclusive federal jurisdiction (02G87####).

This section lists EPA Region 3 permit identifier prefixes and the specific areas where EPA is the permitting authority: The District of Columbia (DCG87####), federal facilities in Delaware (DEG87####E), Indian Country in Virginia (VAG87####E), other Indian Country not covered by an EPA-approved program (03G87####E), and lands of exclusive federal jurisdiction (03G87####).

Identifies EPA Region 4 permit location codes where EPA is the permitting authority: specific Indian Country in Alabama (ALG87####E), Florida (FLG87####E), Mississippi (MSG87####E), and North Carolina (NCG87####E), plus a generic code (04G87####E) for other Indian Country not covered by an EPA-approved state program and 04G87#### for lands of exclusive federal jurisdiction.

Lists EPA Region 5 permit condition codes for Indian Country where EPA is the permitting authority, mapping codes to Illinois (ILG87####E), Indiana (ING87####E), Michigan (MIG87####E), Minnesota (MNG87####E, excluding Fond du Lac and Leech Lake), and Wisconsin (WIG87####E, excluding Lac du Flambeau, Bad River, and Sokaogon). Includes a general code (05G87####E) for other Indian Country not covered by state programs and 05G87#### for all lands of exclusive federal jurisdiction.

Lists EPA Region 6 permitting authority areas and corresponding permit codes: Indian Country within Louisiana (LAG87####E), Oklahoma (OKG87####E), Texas (TXG87####E); New Mexico including Indian Country except Navajo and Ute Mountain (NMG87####); all other Indian Country not otherwise identified and lands of exclusive federal jurisdiction (06G87####E / 06G87####). Useful for locating state-specific EPA permit coverage and code lookup.

Lists permit-condition location codes where EPA is the permitting authority in Region 7: Indian Country within Iowa (IAG87####E), Kansas (KSG87####E), and Nebraska except Pine Ridge Reservation (NEG87####E — Pine Ridge is in Region 8), plus codes for all other Indian Country not covered by an EPA‑approved program (07G87####E) and for Lands of Exclusive Federal Jurisdiction (07G87####).

Lists EPA permit-area codes and the geographic areas where EPA is the permitting authority for Indian Country and federal lands (by state: CO, MT, ND, SD, UT, WY and other Indian Country not covered by state programs), noting specific exceptions (parts of Pine Ridge Reservation, Southern Ute, Goshute and Navajo reservations) and that 08G87 codes cover remaining Indian Country and lands of exclusive federal jurisdiction.

Lists the permit code prefixes (e.g., ASG87, AZG87, CAG87, GUG87, JAG87, MWG87, MPG87, NVG87, 09G87) and the specific geographic areas in EPA Region 9 where EPA is the permitting authority, including certain states, territories, U.S. possessions, and specified Indian Country reservations (with noted exclusions) as well as a code for all other Indian Country and for exclusive federal lands.

Lists areas in EPA Region 10 where EPA is the permitting authority: Indian Country in Alaska, Idaho (except Duck Valley Reservation — see Region 9), and Oregon (except Fort McDermitt Reservation — see Region 9); federal facilities and Indian Country in Washington without an EPA-approved permitting program (e.g., Puyallup trust lands); plus catch-all entries for all other Indian Country not covered by an EPA-approved program and for lands of exclusive federal jurisdiction. Includes location codes (e.g., AKG87####E, IDG87####E, ORG87####E, WAG87####E, 10G87####E).

Explains that you must obtain prior approval from the applicable EPA Regional Office to use a paper Notice of Intent (NOI) instead of electronic filing; specifies two allowable waiver reasons (located in an FCC-designated broadband underserved area or limited computer access), requires recording the EPA staff person’s name and approval date, and otherwise directs users to file electronically via EPA’s NPDES eReporting Tool (NetT).

This section asks applicants to indicate whether the Notice of Intent (NOI) is an original submission for coverage under the 2026 Pesticide General Permit (PGP) or a change of information for an existing covered discharge. If it’s a change, the applicant must provide the NPDES permit tracking number and complete Section B plus any NOI fields being modified.

Collects operator identification details including name, operator type (with NAICS code), whether the operator is a "large entity" (triggering a Pesticide Discharge Management Plan and Annual Report), the single state where pest management occurs, and complete mailing/contact information (address, phone, fax, contact name, and email).

Section C collects detailed information for each Pest Management Area seeking PGP coverage: name and geospatial map (lat/long), whether activities occur on Indian Country or federal land (including exclusive jurisdiction), applicator mailing/contact info, selected pesticide use patterns, and the specific receiving waters covered. It also requires designation of coverage for Tier 2/2.5/3 or impaired waters with associated names, rationale, and supporting evidence or exclusions as applicable.

Section D requires completing an Endangered Species Protection worksheet for each pest management area when applying for PGP coverage, identifying which ESA eligibility criterion (A–G) applies and providing supporting documentation. Applicants must submit a map with geospatial data (generated within 90 days using EPA’s mapping tool) showing the Project Action Area and any overlap with FWS/NMFS Listed Resources of Concern, describe specific avoidance/mitigation measures (including for pest emergencies under Criterion G), and include email notification/coordination with FWS, NMFS, and EPA.

This part of the NOI attachments checklist lists documents to include with a PGP Notice of Intent, including items related to Land of Exclusive Federal Jurisdiction, Tier 3 waters, impaired waters (water quality), ESA protection criteria (A, C–G) and the ESA Criterion Selection Worksheet (see Appendix I), the Pesticide Discharge Management Plan, and any other supporting attachments.

Requires a responsible official to certify under penalty of law that the NOI and attachments were prepared under their direction or supervision and are true, accurate, and complete; includes fields for printed name, title, email, signature, and date and warns of significant penalties for false statements (fines/imprisonment). If someone other than the certifier prepared the NOI, a separate NOI Preparer subsection captures the preparer’s name, organization, phone, date, and email.

This form section collects the NPDES Permit Tracking Number and requires the applicant to select one reason for termination (ceased discharges, obtained individual/alternative permit, or transfer to a new Operator). If transferring, the form requires the transfer date and full contact details for the new Operator (name, address, phone, email), and is part of the paper submission waiver process.

Lists the Operator Information fields required on the paper Notice of Termination (electronic submission waiver) form: operator name, full mailing address (street, city, state, ZIP), telephone number with extension, contact name, and contact email.

The certification requires the responsible official to attest that they meet at least one termination reason, that submitting the Notice of Termination ends authorization to discharge pesticides to U.S. waters, and that the information was prepared under their supervision and is true, accurate, and complete. It warns of significant penalties (fines or imprisonment) for false statements and notes the operator remains liable for any Clean Water Act violations; the form requires printed name, title, email, signature, and date.

This section is the Notice of Termination (NOT) Preparer block to be completed when someone other than the certifier prepared the NOT, typically used with an Approval to Use Paper (electronic submission waiver). It requests the preparer’s name, organization, phone number (and ext.), date, and e‑mail address.

This form (Appendix F, A. General Information) collects operator and preparer names and NPDES tracking number, pest management area ID and name, selected pesticide use pattern, and for each treatment area a location description, area/length, and any waters of the United States receiving discharges.

This worksheet section prompts users to identify the target pest(s), explain why pest control is necessary, and describe pest management measures implemented prior to the first pesticide application as part of EPA’s Pesticide Discharge Evaluation Worksheet for compliance with the PGP.

This section of the Pesticide Discharge Evaluation Worksheet collects applicator contact details, application start/end dates, product names with EPA registration numbers and quantities (lbs or gallons), and the application method (with form fields/slots for multiple products). It also documents whether visual monitoring was conducted (requiring date, time, and location) and asks for descriptions of any observed adverse effects or reasons monitoring was not performed.

Required certification language for the Pesticide Discharge Evaluation Worksheet: signer attests under penalty of law that the submitted information was prepared under their direction/supervision and is true, accurate, and complete, with awareness of penalties for false information. Includes form fields for Printed Name, Title, E‑Mail, Signature/Responsible Official, and Date.

Form fields to record the preparer’s name and organization, contact information (phone, extension, email), and date—to be completed only if someone other than the certifier prepared the Pesticide Discharge Evaluation Worksheet. Includes placeholders for an image/email field.
section_summaries.Appendix G. Annual Report Template > **A: This section lists required general identification and contact information for a paper annual report (electronic submission waiver) for pesticide activities, including NPDES permit tracking number, operator name and full mailing address, telephone and fax, and the primary contact’s name, title, and email for the specified calendar year.

Form asks whether any adverse incidents or corrective actions occurred for each covered pest management area; if yes, complete items 2–6 for each area including incident date, EPA notification details (date, time, contact, instructions), date of the 30‑day written report, and a description and rationale for corrective actions or spill responses.

Per pest management area, the form records whether pesticide discharges occurred and captures use patterns, a geospatial map and size of the treatment area, affected waters and target pests, and whether FWS/NMFS-listed resources were exposed. It also collects visual monitoring results (during and post-application), applicator contact information, PDMP coverage, and total amounts applied by product/EP A reg. number with breakdowns by application method (aerial fixed-wing/rotary, land/aquatic sprayers, direct mixture, chemigation, other).

A responsible official must certify under penalty of law that the report and attachments were prepared under their direction/supervision using a system that ensures qualified personnel gathered and evaluated the information, and that the submission is, to the best of their knowledge, true, accurate, and complete. The certification warns of significant penalties (including fines and imprisonment) for knowingly submitting false information and requires the signer’s printed name, title, e‑mail, signature, and date.

Provides the Annual Report Preparer form fields and filing instructions: reports are submitted via EPA’s NPDES eReporting Tool (NetT) unless an electronic submission waiver is granted, in which case paper reports must be mailed to the EPA (USPS or overnight/express addresses provided) and must be original documents with an ink signature. Specifies who must file (operators required to submit an NOI or meeting threshold/large-entity criteria), the Feb 15 deadline for the prior calendar year (with rules for first/partial-year and termination reporting), and includes NPDES eReporting helpdesk contact information.

Instructions for completing the paper Annual Report (EPA FORM 6100‑25) when an EPA regional office has approved a waiver from electronic reporting: type/print in uppercase, keep a photocopy, and indicate the specific waiver, approving staff person, and approval date. The form collects Section A (permit and contact info), Section B (adverse incidents and corrective actions), Section C (detailed pest management area treatment and monitoring data), and Section D (authorized signature per 40 CFR 122.41(k) and preparer info); the Paperwork Reduction Act estimates an average burden of 8 hours per response.
section_summaries.Appendix G. Annual Report Template > UNI: Defines when an adverse incident under the Pesticide General Permit (PGP) is reportable and lists four exceptions (not related to toxic effects, EPA-waived, clearly erroneous information, or incidents limited to target-like pests per FIFRA label). If reportable, the operator must complete and submit the 30-day written adverse incident report to the appropriate EPA Regional office and the state lead pesticide agency; if not reportable, submission isn’t required but documenting the incident and rationale is recommended.

This section requires the 30-day PGP adverse incident report to include all information provided in the 24‑hour notification: caller contact, operator name and mailing address, NOI/NPDES permit tracking number (or 'NA'), and an alternate contact if applicable. It also requires a description of how and when the operator became aware of the incident, precise location details, each pesticide product applied (with EPA registration numbers), actions taken or planned to remediate impacts, and notifications to other operators or authorities.

Section C of the 30-day Adverse Incident Written Report template records when the operator notified EPA (date and time), the name and title of the EPA person contacted, and any instructions received from EPA. Useful for searches about reporting timelines, who at EPA was contacted, and follow-up guidance provided.

This section lists required elements of the 30-day adverse incident report, including incident location and water appearance, circumstances and species affected (with counts and condition), magnitude/scope of the affected area, habitat and ambient water data, and detailed pesticide application information (rate, intended use site, method, product name, EPA registration number). It also requires noting any laboratory tests (with a summary of results submitted within 5 days if unavailable at filing) and describing actions to prevent recurrence; attachments may be added as needed.

A responsible official must certify under penalty of law that the report and attachments were prepared under their supervision and are true, accurate, and complete; the certification warns of significant penalties for knowingly submitting false information and requires printed name, title, email, signature, and date.

This subsection of the PGP 30-day Adverse Incident Written Report is to be completed only if someone other than the certifier prepared the report. It collects the preparer’s name, organization, telephone (with extension), date, and email for contact and record-keeping.

Instructions for completing the PGP 30‑day Adverse Incident Report, including when incidents are reportable and excluded, required fields carried over from the 24‑hour notification (caller/operator details, NOI/NPDES number, incident description, pesticides used, corrective actions), the date/time and EPA staff contacted, detailed incident data to document (location, species affected, magnitude, application specifics, lab tests, preventive actions), signer eligibility and certification requirements, and the estimated 4‑hour reporting burden and PRA contact info.
section_summaries.Appendix G. Annual Report Template > App: Defines key terms (FWS/NMFS Listed Resources of Concern, Project Action Area, Pest Management Area) and explains that Step 1 requires identifying ESA-listed species and designated critical habitat potentially exposed by pesticide discharges using EPA’s geospatial mapping tool. Emphasizes determining ESA eligibility is required for PGP coverage, notes Section 9 prohibitions on take and potential penalties, and suggests considering Service-recommended measures to minimize exposure.

Use EPA’s geospatial mapping tool to determine whether FWS and/or NMFS Listed Resources of Concern occur in your Project Action Area—the tool provides a map and resource list and will show no entries if none are present. If listed resources are present, proceed to Step 3 (or Step 6 for a Declared Pest Emergency); if none, certify Criterion A and submit the map/list only when an NOI is required (paper NOI waivers must include the map, list, and worksheet).
section_summaries.Appendices > 1.1 Eligibility > 1.1.1 Act: This permit applies to operators who discharge to U.S. waters from the application of biological pesticides or chemical pesticides that leave a residue (collectively “pesticides”), limited to four use patterns: mosquito and other flying insect control, weed and algae pest control, animal pest control (e.g., fish, lampreys, mollusks), and forest canopy pest control where pesticide will be deposited to water.
section_summaries.Appendices > 1.2 Authorization to Discha: Certain eligible discharges are automatically authorized under the permit beginning October 31, 2026 — notably discharges from pesticide research and development (see Appendix A, Part 1.1.2.4 and Table 1-1) and other discharges for which an NOI is not required (see Parts 1.2.2–1.2.3). All other eligible discharges require a Decision-maker to submit a timely, complete, and accurate NOI consistent with Parts 1.2.2 and 1.2.3 to obtain authorization.

Decision-makers identified in Table 1-1 who meet the annual treatment area threshold must submit a Notice of Intent (NOI) to EPA (using the NPDES eReporting Tool unless waived) that identifies the pest management area and any Tier 3 waters by name. EPA will post NOIs online; late NOIs are accepted but authorization is not retroactive, and coverage for the permit duration applies only to activities and personnel listed on a timely, accurate, and complete NOI — applicators who are not Decision-makers do not need to submit an NOI.

Operators with eligible discharges are generally automatically authorized under the permit without submitting an NOI, except for discharges listed in Tables 1-1 through 1-3; Decision-makers with discharges requiring an NOI must submit by the deadlines in Table 1-2 (multiple NOIs are allowed for different activities). EPA may delay authorization, require additional control measures, or deny coverage based on NOI review; special rules in Table 1-2 apply for Declared Pest Emergency Situations (immediate coverage but shorter notification/coordination and reporting requirements with FWS/NMFS).

If this general permit is not reissued before expiration it will be administratively continued under 40 CFR 122.6, and operators authorized before expiration remain covered automatically until the earliest of: coverage under a reissued/replacement permit or timely NOI, a processed Notice of Termination, issuance/denial of an individual NPDES pesticide permit, EPA’s formal decision not to reissue (with a transition period), or EPA notification that the discharge is no longer covered.

Decision-makers required to file an NOI must submit a complete NOT (using EPA’s NeT unless waived) to terminate permit coverage; termination takes effect at 11:59 p.m. the day the NOT is processed and posted on EPA’s pesticide-permitting webpage. NOTs must be filed within 30 days after a new Decision-maker assumes responsibility, after cessation of pesticide discharges with no expected future discharges, or after obtaining alternate NPDES coverage (with a narrow Part 1.3 exception). Decision-makers remain responsible under the permit until termination and must file any required annual report for the portion of the year up to termination (due Feb 15). Operators not required to submit an NOI are terminated when discharges cease or no longer occur.
section_summaries.Appendices > 1.3 Alternative Permits > 1: EPA may require Operators to apply for an NPDES individual or alternative general permit and will notify them in writing with reasons and application instructions. The notice sets a deadline to file (extensions may be granted for good cause); failure to timely apply terminates coverage under the general permit and may subject the Operator to enforcement for unpermitted discharges or permit violations.

Operators who do not want coverage under this general permit can apply for an individual NPDES permit (following 40 CFR 122.26(c)(1)(ii)) by submitting an application and reasons to the appropriate EPA Regional Office (listed in Part 8). If an individual permit is issued or the operator is authorized under an alternative NPDES general permit, coverage under this general permit terminates on the effective/authorization date.
