section_summaries.2.0 Technology-Based Effluent Limitation: Decision-makers required to submit an NOI must, before the first pesticide application and at least annually, establish larval/adult action thresholds, identify target pests and breeding sites, and analyze surveillance or historical data for each pest management area. They must choose and implement measures that minimize pesticide discharges—evaluating prevention, mechanical/cultural, biological, and chemical options—and, if pesticides are used, conduct surveillance and apply only when thresholds are met, preferring larvicides where practicable and using adulticides only when necessary.

Decision-makers required to submit an NOI must, before the first pesticide application and annually, identify pest-affected areas, target pests, contributing factors, and establish site- and pest-specific action thresholds (using other data if needed). They must select and implement Pest Management Measures that minimize discharges—evaluating options (no action, prevention, mechanical/physical, cultural, biological, chemical) for water-quality and non-target impacts, feasibility, and cost. If pesticide use will result in discharge to waters of the U.S., surveillance in representative areas is required prior to each application.

Decision-makers required to submit an NOI must, before the first pesticide application and annually thereafter, identify pest areas, targets, causes, and establish site- and pest-specific action thresholds using available data. They must evaluate and implement Pest Management Measures that minimize discharges (options include no action, prevention, mechanical, cultural, biological, or chemical controls), and if pesticides that may discharge are used, conduct representative pre-application surveillance to determine when to apply.

Decision-makers required to submit an NOI must, before the first pesticide application and annually thereafter, for each pest management area establish pest- and site-specific action thresholds, identify target pests and their distribution, and use available data if recent local data are lacking. They must select and implement Pest Management Measures (no action, prevention, mechanical/physical, cultural, biological, or pesticides) that minimize discharges to waters of the United States while considering water quality, non-target impacts, feasibility, and cost; if pesticides are used, pre-application surveillance and measures to reduce environmental impact are required.
section_summaries.5.0 Pesticide Discharge Management Plan: Decision-makers must list all PDMP team members by name and contact information and specify each person’s responsibilities, including who manages pests for the pest management area, who develops and revises the PDMP, and who develops, revises, and implements corrective actions and other effluent limitation requirements.

Decision-makers must document the pest problem (target pest(s), sources, and data per Parts 2.2.1–2.2.4), define action threshold(s) including data and methods for determining when thresholds are met, include a general location map showing plan boundaries and nearby waters, and note any Tier 3 or impaired waters linked to active ingredients or their degradates.

Decision-makers must document an evaluation of pest management options—including no action, prevention, mechanical/physical, cultural, biological, pesticides, or combinations—used to control target pests. The evaluation must consider impacts to water quality and non-target organisms, feasibility, cost‑effectiveness, and any relevant previous Pest Management Measures.

Requires PDMPs to document procedures for stopping, containing, and cleaning up pesticide leaks/spills (including training, equipment, and PDMP team membership), procedures and notification protocols for adverse incidents (internal and external contact info, medical and responder contacts), and visual monitoring plans (location selection, schedule, responsible person, and documentation of date/time/location).

Decision-makers must retain documentation in the PDMP supporting their determination under Part 1.1.2.4 concerning protection of endangered and threatened species and critical habitat. This documentation is maintained to demonstrate eligibility and compliance with other federal law considerations.

The Pesticide Discharge Management Plan (PDMP) must be signed, dated, and certified by authorized decision-makers in accordance with the legal requirements of 40 CFR 122.41(k). This section specifies the formal signature and certification obligation for compliance.
section_summaries.6.0 Corrective Action > 6.4 Adverse Inci: Within 30 days of a reportable adverse incident (unless Part 6.4.4 applies), Operators must submit a written report to the appropriate EPA Regional office, the state pesticide lead, and Tribal lead if applicable. The report must include initial report info, EPA contact and instructions, incident location and water appearance, affected species and counts, affected area magnitude, pesticide product and application details (rate, site, method, EPA reg. no.), habitat/circumstances and ambient data, lab tests and results (summary within 5 days if delayed), corrective/preventive actions, and signature/certification per 40 CFR 122.41(k).

If an Operator becomes aware an adverse incident from their pesticide discharge may have affected a federally listed threatened/endangered species or designated critical habitat, they must immediately telephone NMFS (for anadromous/marine species) or FWS (for terrestrial/freshwater species) using contacts on EPA’s pesticide permitting page. The call must provide caller and operator contact info, affected species, how/when discovered, incident location and description (including non‑target organisms and signs), pesticide product(s) with EPA registration number(s), and actions taken or planned; Operators should leave organisms alone, document circumstances (location, counts, photos) and follow any specimen‑collection instructions from the Services.

If multiple Operators are authorized for a discharge producing an adverse incident, notification/reporting by any one Operator satisfies the obligation for all Operators, provided the written report required under Part 6.4.2 is also shared with each other authorized Operator within 30 days of the incident.
section_summaries.6.0 Corrective Action > 6.5 Reportable S: Operators must immediately notify the National Response Center (800-424-8802; 202-267-2675 in D.C.) when a spill, leak, or unpermitted discharge of hazardous substances or oil meets or exceeds reportable quantities under 40 CFR Parts 110, 117, or 302. Contact information must be readily accessible at locations where releases may occur, and state or local agencies may require additional reporting.

If a spill, leak, or unpermitted discharge requires notification under Part 6.5.1 but does not cause an adverse incident, the Operator must document and retain specified information within 30 days: the Part 6.5.1 data, a summary of corrective actions with start/completion or expected dates, and measures to prevent recurrence (including whether PDMP modifications are needed). If the event does result in an adverse incident, reporting must follow Parts 6.4.1 and 6.4.2.
section_summaries.8.0 EPA Contact Information and Mailing: Mailing address for EPA Headquarters (via USPS) to send correspondence to the Office of Water, Water Permits Division—ATTN: NPDES Pesticides, Mail Code 4203M. Street address: United States Environmental Protection Agency, 1200 Pennsylvania Avenue NW, Washington, DC 20460.

Provides the overnight/express delivery address for EPA Headquarters: United States Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Water, Water Permits Division, Room 7420, ATTN: NPDES Pesticides, 1201 Constitution Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20004.
Lists the EPA Region 1 Water Division mailing address for Connecticut, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Rhode Island, Vermont, and Maine: 5 Post Office Square, Suite 100, Boston, MA 02109-3912.

Provides EPA Region 2 mailing addresses and office names: Caribbean Environmental Protection Division, Multimedia Permits and Compliance Branch for Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands — City View Plaza II, 48 Carr 165, Suite 7000, Guaynabo, PR 00968-8073; and the Region 2 Water Division for New Jersey and New York — 290 Broadway, 24th Floor, New York, NY 10007-1866.

Gives the mailing/contact address for EPA Region 3's Clean Water Branch (Water Division 3WD41) located at Four Penn Center, 1600 John F. Kennedy Boulevard, Philadelphia, PA 19103. Applies to Region 3 covering Delaware, the District of Columbia, Maryland, Pennsylvania, Virginia, and West Virginia.

Provides the EPA Region 4 Water Protection Division mailing address (Atlanta Federal Center, 61 Forsyth Street SW, Atlanta, GA 30303) and identifies the states served: Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Mississippi, North Carolina, South Carolina, and Tennessee.
Contact information for EPA Region 5 (serving Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Minnesota, Ohio, and Wisconsin): Water Division, Permits Branch (WP-16J), 77 W. Jackson Boulevard, Chicago, IL 60604.

Contact information for U.S. EPA Region 6 Permitting and Water Quality Branch (R6 WD-P) with mailing address: 1201 Elm Street, Suite 500, Dallas, TX 75270. Region 6 serves Arkansas, Louisiana, Oklahoma, Texas, and New Mexico (excluding Navajo — see Region 9 — and Ute Mountain Reservation — see Region 8).

Provides the EPA Region 7 contact information for the Permits and Wetlands (PAW) Branch, Water Division, including the mailing address: 11201 Renner Blvd., Lenexa, KS 66219. Applies to EPA Region 7 covering Iowa, Kansas, Missouri, and Nebraska.

EPA Region 8 serves Colorado, Montana, North Dakota, South Dakota, Wyoming, Utah (excluding Goshute and Navajo Reservations), the Ute Mountain Reservation in New Mexico, and the Pine Ridge Reservation in Nebraska. Mailing/physical address: United States EPA Region 8, 8WD-CWW, 1595 Wynkoop Street, Denver, CO 80202-1129.

Lists the U.S. EPA Region 9 Water Division mailing address (Water Division, WTR-2-3, 75 Hawthorne Street, San Francisco, CA 94105) and the geographic areas served, including AZ, CA, HI, NV, Guam, American Samoa, CNMI, and several reservations (Goshute, Navajo, Duck Valley, Fort McDermitt).

Provides the EPA Region 10 Water Division mailing address and contact location for states served (Alaska, Idaho, Oregon except Fort McDermitt Reservation, and Washington). Address: United States EPA Region 10, Water Division 19-C04, 1200 6th Avenue, Suite 155, Seattle, WA 98101.
section_summaries.9.0 Permit Conditions Applicable Within: Operators in Massachusetts must comply with state water quality standards (including protections for Outstanding Resource Waters and vernal pools), avoid PFAS-leaching containers/formulations where feasible, and follow spill and toxic pollutant rules; MassDEP can halt treatments if they harm uses or non-target species. Weed and algae control generally requires a MassDEP WM04 approval (with specific alum-treatment pH and aluminum testing and reporting requirements), while mosquito and flying insect control requires MDAR-certified applicators and compliance with pesticide and public-notification laws and regulations.
Section 9.1.4 (State of New Hampshire) states that there are no additional, state-specific permit conditions applicable—only the federal permit requirements apply.
For the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico (EPA Region 2), there are no additional state-specific permit conditions—federal/general permit conditions apply as listed elsewhere in the document.

Permittees discharging in the District of Columbia must comply with the D.C. Water Pollution Control Act, DC water quality standards (21 DCMR Ch.11) and monitoring rules (21 DCMR Ch.19), and pesticide laws (DC Law 19-191). Reporting and notification requirements must be provided to the Chief, Illicit Discharge and NPDES Branch, Inspection and Enforcement Division, DDOE (1200 First Street NE, 5th Floor, Washington, DC 20002; phone (202) 805-1355). Federal facilities in Delaware: no additional requirements.

Pesticide applications within Indian Country in Wisconsin—specifically the Lac du Flambeau Band of Lake Superior Chippewa, Bad River Band of Lake Superior Tribe of Chippewa, and Sokaogon Chippewa Community—are not eligible for coverage under this general permit; applicants must contact EPA Region 5 to apply for an individual permit.
Section 9.6.1 states that there are no additional permit conditions applicable within Indian Country in the State of Louisiana.

Operators must comply with the New Mexico Pesticide Control Act, which grants the NMDA authority over pesticides and applicators and establishes definitions, licensing/certification requirements, fee caps, and grounds for license actions. NMAC regulations cited (notably 21.17.50.6) set criteria for pesticide use including licensing, recordkeeping, equipment inspection, and pesticide storage/disposal.

Background explains that Draft PGP Part 1.1.2.2 permits discharges from pesticide applications to Outstanding National Resource Waters (Tier 3) when they restore or maintain water quality or protect public health/environment, provided the discharges either do not degrade water quality or only cause short-term/temporary degradation. This context informs Condition #2 in Section 9.0 on protections specific to ONRWs.

Cites New Mexico regulations requiring a Notice of Intent to Discharge with contact, location, contaminant concentration and quantity information, defines “oversight agency,” and sets an antidegradation policy prohibiting degradation of ONRWs except for narrowly defined temporary public‑health/safety activities subject to a minimum 30‑day public review, controls (best management practices), and time limits (generally not to exceed six months). The section also requires post‑treatment assessment monitoring, public notice to nearby communities, and specific notification and monitoring obligations for discharges covered by NPDES permits; antidegradation reviews apply across permit types (e.g., Sections 402 and 404).

General NPDES permits (e.g., Phase II MS4, MSGP, CGP, PGP, CAFOs) authorize many surface-water discharges but require compliance with permit conditions and BMPs to remain covered. General permits are not subject to a Tier 2 antidegradation review, but new or reissued general permits must be evaluated for potential significant degradation; noncompliant discharges or those causing degradation must obtain an individual permit. EPA Region 6’s NMIP offers implementation guidance for these evaluations.

Cites NM regulations requiring anyone proposing new or altered discharges that may affect surface or ground water to file a notice with the appropriate bureau and include contact, location, concentration, and quantity information (20.6.2.1201 NMAC). The antidegradation policy (20.6.4.8(A) NMAC) permits limited, minimized, and time‑bounded degradation for restoration/maintenance if controls and best practices prevent lowering water quality below that needed to protect existing uses, with reviews based on receiving‑water tier, baseline quality, projected impacts and discharge characteristics. General criteria (20.6.4.13 NMAC) require surface waters be free of toxic pollutants at levels that harm aquatic life, wildlife, livestock or humans.

General NPDES permits (e.g., Phase II MS4, industrial MSGP, construction CGP, pesticide GP, CAFOs) authorize many discharges but require compliance with permit conditions and BMPs; noncompliant discharges or those causing significant degradation must seek individual permits. In New Mexico, general permits are not subject to a full Tier 2 antidegradation review but must be evaluated for potential significant degradation per EPA Region 6’s NMIP, and permit limits/monitoring must protect designated uses, existing higher-quality waters, and the assimilative capacity of receiving waters.

20.6.4.13 NMAC requires surface waters be free of toxic pollutants that harm aquatic life, wildlife or human consumers. 20.6.4.16 NMAC requires applicants proposing piscicide use under an NPDES permit to meet additional notification and monitoring (Subsection G) and submit a Notice of Intent containing petitioner/contact info, piscicide identity and FIFRA/NM registration compliance, target and non‑target (including threatened/endangered) species, environmental impact and mitigation protocols, treatment location and pre‑treatment survey results, alternatives analysis, and documentation of a 30‑day public notice to local entities plus copies of public comments.

This background explains the rationale for Condition #5, noting that Draft PGP Part 5.1.4 requires decision‑makers to have written procedures for notifying appropriate authorities and initiating removal/response actions for spills and other adverse incidents. It frames the notification and removal obligations decision‑makers must follow when incidents occur.

Facility persons must orally notify the chief of the Ground Water Quality Bureau (or appropriate delegated agency) as soon as possible but within 24 hours of any oil/contaminant discharge likely to harm health, wildlife, property, or public welfare, providing details (contact and facility info, date/time/location, source/cause, chemical description, estimated volume, and actions taken). A written verification with any corrections is required within one week; notifications need not duplicate OCC/OCD reporting. Reports are generally protected from criminal use (except for perjury/false statements), the public is urged to report discharges, and the secretary may require corrective actions.

Cites 20.6.2.1201 NMAC: parties proposing new/changed discharges or injections must file a Notice of Intent specifying discharger name/address, discharge location, contaminant concentrations, and quantity; the department will then notify whether a discharge permit is required. The section also lists Pueblo-specific requirements (who to notify, contact emails, timing for NOI/NOT/PDMP submittals, pesticide restrictions or additional action thresholds) and clarifies Table 1 footnotes on criterion assumptions, carcinogen risk levels, adoption of EPA criteria, and sediment/tissue monitoring triggers.

Applicants must provide copies of the Notice of Intent (NOI) and Notice of Termination (NOT) and an electronic Pesticide Discharge Management Plan (PDMP) to the Pawnee Nation Department of Environmental Conservation and Safety (DECS) at the time they are submitted to EPA (mailing address P.O. Box 470, Pawnee, OK 74058 or dnrs@pawneenation.org). DECS must be notified immediately at 918-762-3655 of any permit noncompliance so it can inspect/review activities to ensure compliance with 40 CFR 121.11(a) and Pawnee Nation water protection laws.
For Indian Country within the State of Texas, Condition #6 (Notice of Intent Requirements) imposes no additional requirements beyond the standard permit conditions.

Decision-makers who must submit a Notice of Intent (NOI) to EPA for pesticide applications within the exterior boundaries of the Meskwaki Settlement (Sac and Fox Tribe of the Mississippi in Iowa) are required to provide a copy of the NOI to the Meskwaki Environmental Department prior to application.
For Indian Country within the State of Kansas (EPA Region 7), there are no additional permit conditions or requirements specified in this section.
For Indian Country in Nebraska (except Pine Ridge Reservation, which is covered by Region 8), the Winnebago Tribe of Nebraska has no additional permit requirements specified in this section.

For Indian Country in Colorado and the portion of the Ute Mountain Reservation in New Mexico, pesticide applications within the Southern Ute Indian Tribe are not eligible for discharge coverage under this permit and require contacting EPA Region 8 for an individual permit. The Ute Mountain Ute Tribe has no additional permit requirements.

In EPA Region 8 (Montana) the Confederated Salish and Kootenai Tribes request copies of NOIs sent to 301 Main St, Polson, MT 59860 or evan.smith@cskt.org; Assiniboine & Sioux (Fort Peck), Northern Cheyenne, Blackfeet and most other listed tribal areas in Region 8 have no additional requirements. In Region 9 the Navajo Nation requires courtesy copies of NOIs to Navajo EPA and allows Navajo EPA inspections; several California tribes (Hoopa Valley, Kletsel Dehe Wintun Nation, Morongo Band, Big Pine Paiute) are ineligible for coverage and must apply for individual permits. The Twenty-Nine Palms Band must provide written notification to Tribal EPA for TWQS review and must report discharges within 24 hours; Table Mountain Rancheria and La Posta have no additional requirements.
The Island of Guam has no additional, Guam-specific permit conditions under this section; permittees should follow the general requirements referenced in Part 1.5 and Part 9.0.

For the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands (EPA Region 8), there are no additional permit conditions or territory-specific requirements listed—no requirements beyond the standard federal permit.

Defines “Project Proponent” as entities seeking coverage under the general permit (including agents, assignees, and contractors) and defines “Federal Agency” as the U.S. EPA, which enforces the permit and ensures Project Proponent compliance.

Washington (EPA Region 10) water-quality permit conditions enumerate approved active ingredients and use restrictions for mosquito control, aquatic plant/algae management, noxious weeds, invasive species, irrigation systems, fish/insect/forest treatments, and specify operational limits (littoral‑zone caps, DO monitoring for algaecides, bans/limits on malathion/naled/methoprene in sensitive waters). They require applicator licensing, WDFW consultation and timing windows to protect listed species, Pesticide General Permit coverage (NOI), public notice and shoreline signage, and obligations for notifying/providing replacement water to water-rights holders; statutory citations and agency contacts are provided.

The certification remains valid through the Pesticide General NPDES Permit’s expiration date, including any administrative extensions or the permit’s termination date. Users seeking how long coverage lasts or whether extensions affect certification should refer to this timing requirement.

Project proponents must comply with all Pesticide General NPDES reporting/notification conditions and report to Washington Ecology; appeal rights (30 days) to the PCHB are described with filing procedures and Ecology’s Appeals Processing Desk contact. Contact for region-specific questions is Danielle Edelman (Ecology); the section lists relevant WA statutes/links and notes tribal-specific conditions—most tribes have no extra requirements, but Lummi, Makah, and Jamestown S'Klallam have additional permitting/notification or coordination obligations.

This appendix supplies concise regulatory definitions and citations for terms used in the permit (PGP), including scope-related concepts (Action Area, Action Threshold), pesticide-specific definitions (Active Ingredient per FIFRA/CFR), and what constitutes an Adverse Incident with concrete examples (distressed or dead fish, affected aquatic plants, other non‑target organisms). It also defines Wetlands and references water quality standards and relevant legal authorities.

A.2 provides a table of abbreviations and acronyms with full names used throughout the permit (e.g., EPA, NPDES, CWA, CERCLA, NEPA, FWS, NMFS, NOI, NOT, NeT, LA, MOS, CBI). Use this list to decode statutory, agency, permit-process, and technical terms referenced in the document.

This appendix is the EPA Notice of Intent form and filing instructions for coverage under the Pesticide General Permit, including where and how to submit (NeT required unless waived; U.S. Mail and overnight addresses provided), PDMP and large-entity requirements, filing timelines, and Paperwork Reduction Act info. It describes form sections A–F (NOI status, operator info, pest management area mapping, ESA eligibility and required Criteria A–G documentation, attachments checklist, and certification with signature and penalties) and lists required supporting materials (maps, species overlap lists, PDMP, and other attachments) that users will search for when preparing and submitting an NOI.

Appendix E provides the EPA Notice of Termination (NOT) form (OMB 2040-0004) to end coverage under the Pesticide General Permit (PGP) for discharges from pesticide applications. Users will search for how to terminate PGP coverage, required permittee details (e.g., permit number, reason for termination, last discharge date), signature and certification requirements, and submission instructions.

Operators must file the NOT electronically via EPA’s NeT unless they obtain an EPA Regional Office waiver allowing paper submission (criteria include being in an FCC-identified broadband-underserved area or having limited computer access). If waived, record the waiver type, EPA staff who approved it and the approval date, then mail the original ink-signed paper NOT to the EPA Office of Water at the provided addresses; complete Sections A–C and the NOT preparer block as applicable—unsigned forms won’t terminate coverage and false statements carry federal penalties.

Appendix F supplies the PDEW for small-entity Operators who are Decision‑makers required to submit a NOI under the PGP, outlining required fields and deadlines. It specifies Sections A–D: operator/treatment area identification, pest evaluation and prior controls, pesticide application details (products, EPA reg. numbers, quantities, methods), visual monitoring and adverse effects, and mandatory certifier signature; worksheets must be kept for at least 3 years and key sections completed before or within 14 days after application. The form includes penalty language for false statements and a Paperwork Reduction Act notice (estimated 1-hour burden).
section_summaries.Appendix G. Annual Report Template > UNI: Annual reporting form for Operators (Decision‑makers) required to submit a Notice of Intent (NOI) under the EPA Pesticide General Permit. Reports—identified as OMB No. 2040-0004—must be filed by February 15 for all covered pesticide application discharges during the previous calendar year, per Part 7 of the permit.
section_summaries.Appendix G. Annual Report Template > **A: Provides the paper Annual Report form and instructions for operators granted an EPA regional waiver from electronic reporting, including how to document the waiver, USPS and overnight/express mailing addresses, and the requirement that paper submissions be originals with ink signatures. Explains who must file and the Feb 15 deadline, the required contents of Sections A–D (permit/contact info; adverse incidents and corrective actions; per-pest-area treatment, monitoring, and application details; and certified signature per 40 CFR 122.41(k)), helpdesk contact info, and an estimated 8-hour paperwork burden.
section_summaries.Appendix G. Annual Report Template > UNI: Provides the PGP 30‑day adverse incident report template and instructions: what must be submitted within 30 days after a 24‑hour notification (contact and operator details, NOI/NPDES, precise location, pesticides used with EPA reg. numbers, species affected and magnitude, cleanup/actions, lab data), where to file and who to notify for threatened/endangered species, signer/certification requirements, reporting exceptions, and the estimated 4‑hour paperwork burden.
section_summaries.Appendix G. Annual Report Template > App: This section provides the PGP Eligibility Worksheet and guidance for NOI submittal/review and a six-step process to determine if U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) or National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS) listed species occur in the action area and whether the project meets eligibility under Criteria B, C, D, and F. Steps cover assessing presence of listed resources, eligibility screening, implementing avoidance measures to prevent adverse effects, and handling pesticide applications in declared pest emergencies.

Decision-makers must meet one of six ESA eligibility criteria (A or C–G) for the entire PGP term or they are not eligible for coverage. Step 1 directs users to identify ESA-listed species and designated critical habitat in the Project Action Area using EPA’s geospatial mapping tool, notes key definitions and Section 9 take prohibitions, and advises considering Service-recommended measures to minimize exposure.

Operators whose discharges may expose ESA-listed species and who meet Criteria C–G must submit an NOI for permit coverage (if you can document no exposure, submit an NOI only if otherwise required and indicate Criterion A). After NOI submission the Services have 30 days to advise EPA, and EPA may add conditions, place a hold, or require an individual NPDES permit; if you receive no response within 30 days the discharge is authorized until notified otherwise. Declared Pest Emergency discharges follow special pre-notification/coordination and NOI submittal under Criterion G, and any changes to proposed discharges per Table 1-3 require reevaluation and updating of the NOI.

This worksheet guides determining eligibility for 2026 PGP coverage under ESA Criteria A–G by defining the Project Action Area, using EPA’s geospatial mapping tool to identify FWS/NMFS listed resources, and documenting supporting evidence (maps, species lists, consultations, permits, or Service coordination) in the NOI. It specifies required responses and attachments for each criterion, details reinitiation/eligibility limits, and special filing/notification rules for Declared Pest Emergencies.
section_summaries.PESTICIDE GENERAL PERMIT (PGP) FOR DISCH: Authorizes Operators of point source discharges from pesticide applications to discharge to U.S. waters under the Pesticide General Permit where eligible and located in Appendix C, subject to the permit’s requirements. The permit is organized with general conditions (Parts 1–8), state/tribal conditions (Part 9), definitions/standard conditions (Appendices A–B), and forms/templates (Appendices D–I); it becomes effective Oct 31, 2026 and expires Oct 30, 2031. This is a pre-publication version signed by all 10 EPA Regions on Dec 10, 2024 and will be published in the Federal Register (Docket EPA-HQ-OW-2023-0268).
section_summaries.Appendices > 1.0 Coverage Under This Per: This section explains who is covered by the permit (Operators meeting Part 1.1 eligibility, applicable Part 9 requirements, and, if required, having submitted a Notice of Intent per Part 1.2) and highlights that Operators whose discharges overlap FWS/NMFS-listed resources must submit an NOI. It defines “Operator” as either an Applicator (performs or directs application) or a Decision-maker (controls the decision to apply pesticides), notes multiple Operators can share responsibility for a single discharge, and states that anyone serving as both must meet all applicable requirements for each role.
section_summaries.Appendices > 1.4 Severability: If any part of the permit is invalidated, the rest of the permit remains in effect to the extent possible; the permit is not automatically wholly voided unless EPA issues a written statement saying otherwise.
section_summaries.Appendices > 1.5 Other Federal and State: Operators must comply with all applicable federal and state laws in addition to this permit, notably FIFRA requirements to use pesticides according to label directions and perform required monitoring. Violations of FIFRA (such as exceeding label application rates) can also constitute violations of this permit and the CWA. Other statutes and agency rules (for example, U.S. Coast Guard regulations) may also apply to covered activities.
section_summaries.Appendices > 1.6 Federally-Listed Endang: Operators must comply with any conditions or requirements that address discharges when those stem from prior ESA Section 7 consultations or ESA Section 10 permits issued by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) or National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS). The section ties permit compliance to pre-existing federal actions affecting listed species and designated critical habitat.
section_summaries.2.0 Technology-Based Effluent Limitation: Applicators must follow Part 2.1 to minimize pesticide discharges by using Pest Management Measures: apply only the amount and frequency necessary (unless specified by a Decision-maker), maintain and calibrate equipment to prevent leaks or spills, and assess weather (temperature, precipitation, wind) to ensure applications comply with federal requirements.

Decision-makers must implement Pest Management Measures to minimize pesticide discharges to U.S. waters and, where they must submit an NOI, establish site- and pest-specific action thresholds, identify target pests and sources, and analyze surveillance/historical data before first application and annually. They must evaluate non-chemical and chemical control options for water-quality and non-target impacts, conduct representative pre-application surveillance when discharges are likely, and use least-disruptive methods (e.g., larvicides over adulticides for mosquitoes) consistent with feasibility and cost.
section_summaries.4.0 Monitoring > 4.1 Visual Monitoring R: Applicators must visually assess treatment areas, when safe and feasible, for observable adverse incidents (e.g., unanticipated death/distress of non-target organisms or disruption of wildlife habitat and water uses) and document those observations per Part 4.3; EPA can require further monitoring per Part 4.4.
section_summaries.4.0 Monitoring > 4.2 Visual Monitoring R: All Operators must visually assess the area during post-application surveillance of pesticide discharges authorized under this permit for observable adverse incidents (per Appendix A), such as unanticipated death or distress of non-target organisms and disruption of wildlife habitat or recreational/municipal water use. Visual monitoring must be documented as required in Part 4.3, and EPA may mandate additional monitoring under Part 4.4.
section_summaries.4.0 Monitoring > 4.3 Documentation of Vi: Requires For-Hire Applicators and any Decision-maker required to submit an NOI to document the findings of each visual monitoring event—or explicitly record the reason no visual monitoring was conducted (per Parts 7.2–7.4)—to ensure compliance and proper recordkeeping.
section_summaries.4.0 Monitoring > 4.4 Additional Monitori: EPA may require additional monitoring to ensure compliance with Part 2 and/or Part 3 of the permit and will notify the Operator when required. The notice will specify the reasons for additional monitoring and detail locations and parameters to be monitored, monitoring frequency and period, sample types, and reporting requirements.
section_summaries.5.0 Pesticide Discharge Management Plan: Lists required PDMP contents: identification of a PDMP team with roles/contact information; documentation of pest problems and action thresholds with maps; evaluation of management options (including water-quality/non‑target impacts, feasibility, and cost); response procedures for spills and adverse incidents plus visual monitoring protocols; retention of documentation supporting eligibility under other federal laws (e.g., endangered species considerations); and required signature/certification per 40 CFR 122.41(k).

Decision-makers must update the PDMP whenever corrective-action triggers (Part 6.1) occur or when pest-control changes significantly alter pollutant type/quantity. Revisions must be made before the next pesticide application if practicable (or within 90 days), signed/dated per 40 CFR 122.41(k), and an updated PDMP submitted to EPA within 15 business days.

Decision-makers must submit the Pesticide Discharge Management Plan (PDMP) with their NOI, retain a copy, and provide copies to state, Tribal, or local discharge/pesticide agencies or representatives of the Services upon request; the PDMP and supporting documents will be posted on EPA’s website with the NOI. Confidential Business Information (CBI) may be withheld from the public if properly claimed under 40 CFR Part 2 but must be provided to EPA if requested and is accessible to EPA, FWS, and NMFS staff cleared for CBI review.
section_summaries.6.0 Corrective Action > 6.1 Situations R: Operators must review and, if necessary, revise Pest Management Measures (per Parts 2.1/2.2) when certain events occur: unauthorized pesticide releases or discharges, findings that measures are inadequate to meet Part 3 effluent limits, monitoring showing failure to meet Part 2 technology-based limits, agency inspections/evaluations requiring changes, or any adverse incident defined in Appendix A.
section_summaries.6.0 Corrective Action > 6.2 Corrective A: Operators must make required changes to Pest Management Measures to correct issues identified in Part 6.1 before the next pesticide application that will cause a discharge, or if that is not practicable, as soon as possible after that application.
section_summaries.6.0 Corrective Action > 6.3 Effect of Co: Correcting a condition noted in Part 6.1 does not eliminate liability for the original permit violation, and failure to follow Part 6.2 constitutes an additional permit violation. The EPA may impose further or more stringent requirements and compliance schedules (including requests for more information), and those requirements will supersede Parts 6.1 and 6.2 where they conflict.
section_summaries.6.0 Corrective Action > 6.6 Other Correc: For non-adverse, non-reportable situations identified under Part 6.1, Operators must document the triggering condition and planned corrective actions within 30 days and retain the record. The documentation must record condition identification (including monitoring), a brief description, date and method of discovery, summary and timeline of corrective actions, and measures to prevent recurrence—stating if PDMP modifications are needed.
section_summaries.7.0 Recordkeeping and Annual Reporting >: All operators are required to retain copies of adverse incident reports, written rationale for any determination not to report an identified adverse incident, corrective action documentation, and records of spills, leaks, or other unpermitted discharges.

For-hire applicators must retain equipment calibration records and detailed records for each treatment area including a map/description with size and nearby waters, pesticide use pattern and target pest, product name and EPA registration number, quantity applied, application dates, and visual monitoring information (including date/time/location, reasons if monitoring wasn’t done, and any observed or possible adverse incidents).

Small entities required to submit an NOI must retain at the NOI address copies of the NOI, EPA correspondence/acknowledgment, applicator calibration records (if applicable), and detailed records for each treatment area. Treatment-area records must include maps/locations and sizes, use patterns, target pests and rationale, pre-application pest management measures, applicator contact, pesticide product names and EPA reg. numbers, quantities, application start/end dates, and visual monitoring details (date/time/location and any observed incidents); a worksheet is provided in Appendix F.

Large entities required to submit an NOI must keep at the NOI address copies of the NOI and EPA correspondence/acknowledgment, the PDMP (and modifications), annual reports, and equipment calibration records if they serve as the applicator. They must also retain detailed records for each treatment area—maps/locations and sizes, use patterns, target pests and need, action thresholds and methods used to determine them, prior pest management measures, applicator company/contact, pesticide product names and EPA registration numbers, quantities and application dates, and whether visual monitoring occurred and any observed adverse incidents.

Operators must document required pesticide application records as soon as possible and no later than 14 days after each application, retain those records for at least 3 years after their permit coverage ends or is terminated, and make records available to the EPA (and provide copies) upon request.

Decision-makers defined as large entities who must submit an NOI must file an annual report to EPA (electronically via NeT unless waived or unavailable) by February 15 for the prior calendar year and must continue filing each year of permit coverage even if no discharges occur. Reports must include contact and permit information, maps/locations and sizes of treatment areas, applicator(s), total pesticide products applied by EPA registration number and application method, dates of any discharges affecting listed resources, adverse-incident and corrective-action summaries, copies of visual monitoring records, and whether the activity was in the PDMP; special rules apply for first-year threshold exceedances and termination-year partial reporting.

Small entities with discharges to U.S. waters or discharge-related activities that may expose FWS/NMFS-listed resources must submit an annual EPA report (via NeT unless waived) by February 15 covering the prior calendar year. Reports must include monitoring records, decision-maker contact and permit numbers, and per-treatment-area details (maps/geospatial data, location/size, receiving waters, and pesticide use patterns); the requirement persists each year of permit coverage and a final partial-year report is due upon termination.

Decision-makers must submit NOIs, NOTs, and annual reports electronically unless granted a waiver. Waivers are available if the Decision-maker is located in an FCC-identified underserved broadband area or has limited computer access/capability; requests must be sent to the appropriate EPA Regional Office (contact info in Part 8.2) with evidence and a completed NOI, and are effective only after written EPA confirmation.
section_summaries.9.0 Permit Conditions Applicable Within: For EPA Region 2 Indian Country in New York, the St. Regis Mohawk Tribe has no additional permit requirements, while the Seneca Nation requires submitters to provide copies of NOIs and NOTs to its Environmental Protection Department within three business days, allow access to permits for WQS review, and submit Pesticide Discharge Management Plans electronically at least 10 days before application. The section cites relevant tribal ordinance and 40 CFR authorities and includes the Seneca Nation EPD contact (epd@sni.org and mailing address). The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico has no additional state-specific permit conditions.

Section 9.4 (EPA Region 4) lists Indian Country areas in Alabama, Florida (Miccosukee and Seminole Tribes), Mississippi, and North Carolina (Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians) and notes that there are no additional permit requirements for any of these jurisdictions.

Lists permit conditions for Indian Country in EPA Region 5 (MI, MN, WI). Several tribes (Fond du Lac, Leech Lake, Lac du Flambeau, Bad River, Sokaogon) are ineligible for general permit coverage and must contact EPA for individual permits; Keweenaw Bay and Red Lake Nation have no additional requirements. Grand Portage has detailed conditions including a Lake Superior no-discharge zone, required submission of a Pesticide Discharge Management Plan, monitoring/reporting requirements, spill reporting, and enforcement/appeal provisions.

EPA will include a comment in Part 9 of the Final PGP requiring operators in New Mexico to comply with the New Mexico Pesticide Control Act (NMSA 1978 §§76-4-1 to -39) and related NMAC rules (Title 21, Ch. 17, Parts 50, 51, 53, 56) administered by the New Mexico Department of Agriculture. Key compliance elements include licensing/certification of applicators, recordkeeping, equipment inspection, pesticide storage and disposal, fee limits, and grounds for license actions.

Operators are not eligible for this permit for discharges to Tier 3 Outstanding Natural Resource Waters (ONRWs) in New Mexico except when the pesticide application is for restoration or maintenance; such projects require submission of the NOI, project plan, and NOT to NMED for case‑by‑case review. Operators must demonstrate that any degradation will be minimized, temporary, will not lower water quality below levels needed to protect existing uses or alter the ONRW’s essential character, and discharges that fail these antidegradation criteria must obtain an individual permit (NMED contact information provided).

For pesticide discharges to surface waters (not ONRWs) that may cause temporary or short‑term degradation during restoration/maintenance, operators must submit the NOI, project plan, and NOT to the New Mexico Environment Department for case‑by‑case antidegradation review showing impacts will be time‑limited, minimized using BMPs/permit requirements, and will not lower water quality below that needed to protect existing uses. Discharges that cannot meet these antidegradation criteria must obtain an individual permit; submittals and questions should be sent to NMED Surface Water Quality Bureau (contact details provided).

Condition #4 requires operators covered by the permit to comply with New Mexico water quality standards (20.6.4.13 NMAC) and the additional notification and monitoring requirements in 20.6.4.16 NMAC. Operators must provide written notice to local political subdivisions, water planning entities, conservancy/irrigation districts and media, submit detailed Notices of Intent for piscicide use (including pesticide identity, target/non‑target species, mitigation, pre‑treatment surveys, alternatives analysis, and 30‑day public notice documentation), and implement post‑treatment assessment monitoring with public notice to immediate and near downstream areas.

Condition #5 requires operators to follow New Mexico spill and adverse-incident notification and removal rules (20.6.2.1203 NMAC), including oral notification to the Ground Water Quality Bureau chief within 24 hours and a written verification within one week. The section lists emergency (505-827-9329) and non-emergency (866-428-6535) contacts and the NMED Surface Water Quality Bureau contact, and explains that facilities must have written procedures and may be required to take corrective/removal actions; reports are generally protected from criminal use.

Condition #6 requires operators in New Mexico to file NOIs with the NMED Ground Water Quality Bureau and/or Surface Water Quality Bureau for discharges that may affect groundwater or surface water (contact addresses, phone numbers, and preferred emails are provided). The section details Tribe- and Nation-specific notification, timing, PDMP and reporting variations (e.g., Isleta bans restricted-use pesticides within its exterior boundaries and needs concurrent mail/email; Sandia and Santa Clara require electronic NOI/NOT within three business days and PDMP timing; Picuris and others have accelerated submission or certified-NOI rules), notes pueblos with no extra NOI requirements (Taos, Pojoaque, some Texas Indian Country), and includes Table 1 footnote guidance on criteria, carcinogen risk basis, and sediment/tissue monitoring triggers.

EPA Region 10 permit conditions cover Indian Country in AK, ID, OR and detailed Washington requirements for aquatic pesticide use, listing approved active ingredients and operational limits (littoral-zone treatment caps, DO monitoring for algaecides, bans/limits on malathion/naled/methoprene). They require licensed applicators, WDFW consultation and timing windows, NOI/coverage under the Pesticide General NPDES Permit, public notice and shoreline signage, notification/provision of replacement water to water-rights holders, and identify a few tribes (Lummi, Makah, Jamestown S'Klallam) with additional permitting or notification obligations; appeal and contact procedures are provided.

This section reproduces the standard permit conditions in 40 CFR §122.41 that apply to all NPDES permits, including the permittee’s duty to comply, how conditions must be incorporated into permits, and enforcement consequences (e.g., permit modification, termination, civil penalties). It stresses compliance with CWA effluent and sewage sludge standards, notes civil penalty amounts are adjusted annually (see 40 C.F.R. §19.4), and outlines the elements and burden of proof for asserting an "upset" affirmative defense (cause identification, contemporaneous operating logs, 24-hour notice, and required remedial measures).

Lists the 2026 PGP geographic coverage by EPA region, mapping permit-location code prefixes to specific states, territories, Indian Country areas, federal facilities, and lands of exclusive federal jurisdiction. Notes reservation and jurisdictional exceptions and provides catch‑all codes for other Indian Country and exclusive federal lands to aid permit-code lookup and determining where EPA is the NPDES permitting authority.

Appendix D is the EPA Notice of Intent (NOI) form and filing instructions for PGP coverage: applicants must use the NPDES eNOI Tool (NeT) unless granted a regional waiver to submit a signed paper NOI to EPA (addresses provided), include required attachments such as a PDMP, species overlap maps, and ESA Criterion documentation (A–G), and complete certification. The appendix also explains large-entity obligations, submission deadlines/authorization timing, mapping requirements for the Project Action Area, and Paperwork Reduction Act burden information.

Appendix E provides the EPA Notice of Termination (NOT) form and instructions for ending PGP coverage; operators must file electronically via the NPDES eNOI/NeT unless granted a regional waiver to submit an original ink-signed paper NOT to the EPA mailing/overnight addresses. The form collects the permit tracking number and reason for termination, operator/contact details, certification and authorized signature (with preparer block if completed by another person), and must be filed within 30 days after applicable permit termination conditions.

Small-entity Operators who are Decision‑makers required to file a Notice of Intent under the PGP may use this Pesticide Discharge Evaluation Worksheet (PDEW). The form requires Sections A–D: operator/treatment area identification, pest evaluation and prior controls, pesticide application details (product names and EPA registration numbers, quantities, methods), visual monitoring and adverse effects, and a certified signature; Section B must be completed before application and most of Section C within 14 days after the first application, with worksheets retained for at least 3 years. The PDEW includes signer responsibility/penalty language and a Paperwork Reduction Act burden notice.
section_summaries.Appendix G. Annual Report Template > App: Decision-makers must use EPA’s geospatial mapping tool to identify FWS/NMFS listed species or designated critical habitat in the Project Action Area and meet one of the PGP ESA eligibility criteria (A or C–G) for permit coverage. If listed resources may be exposed, submit an NOI with required documentation (maps, species lists, consultation/permit correspondence) and follow special coordination and timing rules for Declared Pest Emergencies; prior Section 7/10 coverage or Service concurrence can satisfy eligibility, while pending reinitiation can make projects ineligible.
section_summaries.Contents: This is the document's table of contents, listing section titles and page numbers for permit topics including coverage, eligibility, authorization to discharge, alternative permits, severability, other federal/state requirements, and federally-listed species/critical habitat. It also indexes EPA Region-specific information to help users quickly find regulatory and regional guidance within the permit.
section_summaries.Appendices: The Appendices collect supporting reference materials and required forms for permit compliance — e.g., definitions and abbreviations (App A), standard permit conditions (App B), geographic coverage (App C), mandatory forms (NOI in App D; NOT in App E), evaluation and eligibility worksheets (App F and App I), and reporting templates (Apps G and H). These resources are the primary search targets for users needing forms, templates, evaluation tools, or ESA-related documentation referenced throughout the permit (notably Part 1 NOI/NOT and species protection procedures).
section_summaries.2.0 Technology-Based Effluent Limitation: Sets technology-based effluent limits for Operators (Applicators and Decision-makers) requiring establishment of site- and pest-specific action thresholds, evaluation and implementation of non-chemical and chemical pest management measures to minimize discharges, and representative pre-application surveillance when discharges to U.S. waters are likely. Decision-makers who must file an NOI must perform these assessments before the first application and annually; applicators must apply only as needed, maintain/calibrate equipment, consider weather, and follow legal requirements. For mosquito control, larvicides are preferred over adulticides when practicable.
section_summaries.3.0 Water Quality-Based Effluent Limitat: Sets water-quality-based effluent limits prohibiting pesticide discharges that cause observable floating solids, scum, sheen, oil films, foam, discoloration, or odor beyond what is expected from FIFRA-compliant application. Prohibits discharges to waters listed as impaired for the pesticide active ingredient or its degradate and to state/Tribal-designated Tier 3 waters except as allowed, and requires corrective actions (up to ceasing discharge) if noncompliance is identified.
section_summaries.5.0 Pesticide Discharge Management Plan: Large Decision-makers filing an NOI must prepare and submit a Pesticide Discharge Management Plan (PDMP) describing team roles, pest/problem identification and action thresholds (with maps), evaluation of management options, spill/incident response and visual monitoring procedures, and documentation supporting other federal law determinations; the PDMP must be signed/certified under 40 CFR 122.41(k). PDMPs must be updated when corrective-action triggers or major pesticide changes occur (revisions before next application or within 90 days, and submitted to EPA within 15 business days), and are retained and posted with the NOI while properly claimed CBI may be withheld from public disclosure.
section_summaries.6.0 Corrective Action: Operators must promptly report adverse pesticide discharge incidents (24-hour phone notice to EPA; detailed 30-day written report) and immediately notify FWS/NMFS for impacts to listed species or critical habitat; spills reaching reportable quantities require National Response Center notification. Operators must revise pest management measures and document corrective actions (before the next discharge or ASAP), retain records for non‑reportable events, and note that corrective action does not remove prior liability.
section_summaries.7.0 Recordkeeping and Annual Reporting: This section defines recordkeeping and annual reporting obligations for different operator types (all operators, for‑hire applicators, Decision‑makers who are small or large entities), references Table 7‑1 for applicable requirements, and lists required records (treatment area details, calibration, monitoring, adverse‑incident and corrective‑action documentation). It also sets timing and retention rules (document within 14 days, retain records at least 3 years after permit termination), annual reporting rules for large Decision‑makers and certain small Decision‑makers (file by Feb 15 via NeT), and the electronic‑reporting waiver process.
section_summaries.8.0 EPA Contact Information and Mailing: Requires Decision-makers to submit NOI, NOT, and annual reports via EPA’s NPDES eReporting Tool (NeT) unless NeT is unavailable or a waiver is granted—if unavailable/waived, submit to EPA Headquarters addresses provided. Operators must send incident reports within 30 days to the appropriate EPA Regional Office and the state/tribal pesticide lead agency. The section lists the USPS and overnight addresses for EPA Headquarters and detailed mailing/office addresses for EPA Regions 1–10, including special jurisdictional notes for certain reservations and territories.
section_summaries.9.0 Permit Conditions Applicable Within: Section 9 documents modifications and additions to the Pesticide General Permit that apply in specific states, territories, Indian Country and federal lands, including detailed NOI/NOT/PDMP submission procedures (timing, email/mail/overnight addresses, and electronic‑filing waivers), tribe‑specific notification and pesticide restrictions, and regionally tailored operational conditions (notably Washington aquatic use limits and New Mexico antidegradation/spill rules). It also summarizes Table 1 footnotes on water‑quality criteria and monitoring triggers, ESA eligibility/mapping requirements, EPA regional permit‑code mappings, and where to find the NOI/NOT/PDEW forms, retention, certification, and appeal procedures.
section_summaries.Appendix G. Annual Report Template: Appendix G provides the paper Annual Report form and instructions for PGP operators (used only with an EPA waiver from NetT), including USPS/overnight addresses, Feb 15 filing deadline, required Sections A–D (permit/contact info, adverse incidents/corrective actions, per‑pest area treatment/monitoring, and certified signature), and PRA burden estimates. It also includes the 24‑hour notification and 30‑day adverse incident report templates and requirements, ESA eligibility screening (Criteria A–G) guidance and documentation requirements, signer certification rules under 40 CFR 122.41(k), and NPDES eReporting helpdesk/contact info.

chunks.content: **PRE-PUBLICATION NOTICE.** All 10 U.S. Environmental Protection Agency Regions signed the following document on December 10, 2024, and EPA is submitting it for publication in the Federal Register (FR). This document is not disseminated for purposes of EPA's Information Quality Guidelines and does not represent an Agency determination or policy. While we have taken steps to ensure the accuracy of this Internet version of the document, it is not the official version. Please refer to the official version in a forthcoming FR publication, which will appear on the Government Printing Office's govinfo website (<https://www.govinfo.gov/app/collection/fr>). It will also appear on Regulations.gov (<https://www.regulations.gov>) in Docket No. EPA-HQ-OW-2023-0268. Once the official version of this document is published in the FR, this version will be removed from the internet and replaced with a link to the official version.

header_path.name: Appendices

metadata.Header 1: Appendices

chunks.content:
This permit covers any Operator who meets the eligibility requirements identified in Part 1.1, requirements in Part 9 imposed by applicable states (including territories) or Tribes, and if so required, has submitted a Notice of Intent (NOI) in accordance with Part 1.2.

Note: All Operators with discharges covered by this permit and discharge-related activities that overlap with U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) or National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS) Listed Resources of Concern are required to submit an NOI. See Part 1.1.2.4, Table 1-1, and Appendix I for the information Decision-maker must submit with their NOI and for Endangered Species Act (ESA) eligibility criteria that must be met.

header_path.name: Appendices
1.0 Coverage Under This Permit

metadata.Header 1: Appendices

chunks.content: For the purpose of this permit, “Operator” is defined in Appendix A to mean any entity associated with the application of pesticides which results in a discharge to waters of the United States that meets either of the following two criteria: (1) any entity who performs the application of a pesticide or who has day-to-day control of the application (*i.e.*, they are authorized to direct workers to carry out those activities); or (2) any entity with control over the decision to perform pesticide applications including the ability to modify those decisions. Operators identified in (1) above are referred to in this permit as Applicators while Operators identified in (2) are referred to in this permit as Decision-makers. As defined, more than one Operator may be responsible for complying with this permit for any single discharge from the application of pesticides.

header_path.name: Appendices
1.0 Coverage Under This Permit

metadata.Header 1: Appendices

chunks.content:
For purposes of this permit, all Operators are defined as either an Applicator or a Decision-maker or both an Applicator and a Decision-maker.

When an Operator is both an Applicator and a Decision-maker, the Operator must comply with all applicable requirements imposed on both Applicators and Decision-makers. When the permit references all “Operators,” both Applicators and Decision-makers must comply.

header_path.name: Appendices
1.0 Coverage Under This Permit

metadata.Header 1: Appendices

chunks.content:
This permit is available to Operators who discharge to waters of the United States from the application of (1) biological pesticides or (2) chemical pesticides that leave a residue (collectively called *pesticides*), when the pesticide application is for one of the following pesticide use patterns:

- a. **Mosquito and Other Flying Insect Pest Control**—to control public health/nuisance and other flying insect pests that develop or are present during a portion of their life cycle in or above standing or flowing water. Public health/nuisance and other flying insect pests in this use category include mosquitoes and black flies.
- b. **Weed and Algae Pest Control**—to control weeds, algae, and pathogens that are pests in water and at water’s edge, including ditches and/or canals.
- c. **Animal Pest Control**—to control animal pests in water and at water’s edge. Animal pests in this use category include fish, lampreys, insects, mollusks, and pathogens.

header_path.name: Appendices
1.1 Eligibility
1.1.1 Activities Covered

metadata.Header 1: Appendices

chunks.content: d. **Forest Canopy Pest Control**—application of a pesticide to a forest canopy to control the population of a pest species (e.g., insect or pathogen) where, to target the pests effectively, a portion of the pesticide unavoidably will be applied over and deposited to water.

chunks.content: Operators are not eligible for coverage under this permit for any discharges from a pesticide application to waters of the United States if the water is identified as impaired by a substance which either is an active ingredient in that pesticide or is a degradate of such an active ingredient.

header_path.name: Appendices

1.1.2 Limitations on Coverage
1.1.2.1 *Discharges to Water Quality Impaired Waters*

metadata.Header 1: Appendices
metadata.Header 4: 1.1.2.1 *Discharges to Water Quality Impaired Waters*

chunks.content: For purposes of this permit, impaired waters are those that have been identified by a state, Tribe, or EPA pursuant to Section 303(d) of the CWA as not meeting applicable state or tribal water quality standards. Impaired waters, for the purposes of this permit, consist of both waters with EPA-approved or EPA-established total maximum daily loads (TMDLs) and waters for which EPA has not yet approved or established a TMDL. A list of those waters is available at <https://www.epa.gov/tmdl/>. If a discharge from a pesticide application would not be eligible under this permit because the water is listed as impaired for that specific pesticide, but there is evidence that shows the water is no longer impaired, Operators may submit this information to EPA consistent with Table 1-2 in Part 1.2.3, and request that coverage be allowed under this permit.

chunks.content: Except for discharges from pesticide applications made to restore or maintain water quality or to protect public health or the environment that either do not degrade water quality or only degrade water quality on a short-term or temporary basis, Operators are not eligible for coverage under this permit for discharges to waters of the United States if the water is designated by a state or Tribe as Tier 3 (Outstanding National Resource Waters) for antidegradation purposes under Title 40 of the *Code of Federal Regulations* (CFR) 131.12(a)(3). A list of Tier 3 waters is available on EPA's website at <https://www.epa.gov/npdes/pesticide-permitting>.

chunks.content:
Discharges are not eligible for coverage under this permit if any of the following circumstances apply:

- The discharge is covered by another NPDES permit, or
- The discharge was included in a permit that in the past 5 years has been or is in the process of being denied, terminated, or revoked by EPA (this does not apply to the routine reissuance of permits every 5 years).

chunks.content: Activities that meet one of the ESA eligibility criteria (A through G) are not likely to result in any short- or long-term adverse effects to species that are federally-listed as endangered or threatened (“listed”) under the Endangered Species Act (ESA) or habitat that is federally-designated as critical under the ESA (“critical habitat”), except as provided in eligibility Criteria C, D, and, for 60 days, G. Under Criteria C and D, effects to listed species and critical habitat have already been addressed through a separate Section 10 permit, or Section 7(a)(2) consultation. Under Criterion G, effects to listed species and critical habitat have already been addressed through the coordination with the Services.

metadata.Header 1: Appendices
metadata.Header 4: 1.1.2.4 *Endangered and Threatened Species and Critical Habitat Protection*

chunks.content: As one of the provisions in this permit that help limit adverse effects to these resources, the six eligibility criteria (A-G) relate to the impacts a prospective discharger’s activities may have on listed species and critical habitat. Specifically, the conditions in the ESA eligibility criteria relate to potential impacts on Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) Listed Resources of Concern as defined in Appendix A and National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS) Listed Resources of Concern as defined in Appendix A. These are resources that have been identified through consultation with FWS and NMFS on the PGP as having potential exposure to pesticides from discharges and discharge-related activities that warrant the additional protections entailed in compliance with eligibility criteria A-G. Other provisions that protect listed species more broadly include Part 1.6, which requires compliance with any conditions resulting from an ESA Section 7 consultation or ESA Section 10 permit; Part 6.4.3,

To be eligible for coverage under this permit, Decision-makers must meet one of the following six eligibility criteria (A-G) for the entire term of coverage under the permit and, if required to submit an NOI, are required to provide the supporting documentation with the NOI:

**Criterion A.** Pesticide application activities will not result in a point source discharge to one or more waters of the United States or involve discharge-related activities that may expose FWS Listed Resources of Concern and NMFS Listed Resources of Concern to pollutants. If this pesticide application is in response to a Declared Pest Emergency Situation, see Criterion G.

chunks.content: **Criterion D.** Pesticide application activities for which permit coverage is being requested will discharge to one or more receiving waters of the United States and/or involve discharge-related activities that may expose FWS Listed Resources of Concern and/or NMFS Listed Resources of Concern to pollutants, but consultation with FWS and/or NMFS under section 7 of the ESA has been concluded for pesticide application activities covered under this permit. Consultations can be either formal or informal and would have occurred only as a result of a separate federal action. The consultation addressed the effects of pesticide discharges to waters of the United States and discharge-related activities on federally-listed threatened or endangered species and federally-designated critical habitat based on the list of FWS Listed Resources of Concern and NMFS Listed Resources of Concern generated within 90 days of NOI submittal. The consultation must have resulted in either:

Prior to any discharge to waters of the United States under Criterion G, Decision-makers must notify and begin to coordinate with FWS and NMFS. Notification shall occur and coordination shall begin as soon as possible after determining that pesticide application is required in response to a Declared Pest Emergency Situation. As part of any coordination, technical assistance or recommendations provided by the Services for avoiding any short- or long-term adverse effects during the emergency should be implemented as prescribed either before or after discharge has begun, as applicable) to be eligible for coverage under the permit. The Decision-makers must provide documentation of the coordination and written

The following discharges, consistent with the permit eligibility provisions in Part 1.1, are automatically authorized by this permit beginning October 31, 2026.

- Eligible discharges that result from the application of a pesticide as part of *pesticide research and development* as defined in Appendix A. See Part 1.1.2.4 and Table 1-1 for discharges that require an NOI;
- Eligible discharges for which submission of an NOI is not required. See Parts 1.2.2 and 1.2.3.

To obtain authorization under this permit for all other eligible discharges, a Decision-maker must submit a timely, complete, and accurate NOI consistent with the requirements of Parts 1.2.2 and 1.2.3.

chunks.content: If required to submit an NOI, a Decision-maker must submit the NOI once, in accordance with the deadlines in Part 1.2.3, Table 1-2. The Decision-maker must submit an updated NOI if the criteria in Part 1.2.3, Table 1-3 are met. The Decision-maker must prepare and submit the NOI using [EPA's NPDES eReporting Tool \(NeT\)](#) unless NeT is otherwise unavailable, or the Decision-maker has obtained a waiver from the requirement to use NeT for submission of the NOI. See Part 7.8 for detailed electronic reporting requirements. EPA will immediately post on the EPA's website all NOIs received. Late NOIs will be accepted, but authorization to discharge will not be retroactive.

chunks.content:
Coverage will be available for the duration of the permit for Decision-makers who file an NOI, including the Decision-makers' employees, contractors, subcontractors, and other agents, for all activities identified on the NOI unless coverage is terminated pursuant to Parts 1.2.5 or 1.3. If a submitted NOI is not timely, accurate, or complete, any employee, contractor, subcontractor or other entity that discharges without the required NOI is not covered by this permit.

Applicators who are not also Decision-makers do not need to submit an NOI.

chunks.content: **1.2.5.1 Submitting a Notice of Termination (NOT).** To terminate permit coverage, a Decision-maker who is required to submit an NOI as identified in Part 1.2.2 must submit a complete and accurate Notice of Termination. Information required to be included in an NOT is provided in Appendix E of this permit. Decision-makers required to submit an NOT must prepare and submit that information using EPA's NPDES eReporting Tool (NeT) unless NeT is otherwise unavailable, or EPA waives the electronic submission requirement for an Operator consistent with the requirements in Part 7.8. The authorization to discharge under this permit terminates at 11:59 p.m. of the day that a complete NOT is processed and posted on EPA's website at <https://www.epa.gov/npdes/pesticide-permitting>. If a Decision-maker submits an NOT without meeting one or more of the conditions identified in Part 1.2.5.2, the NOT is not valid. Decision-makers are responsible for complying with the terms of this permit until

chunks.content: If EPA requires an Operator to apply for an NPDES individual permit, EPA will notify the Operator in writing that a permit application is required. Such a notification will include a brief statement of the reasons for the decision and will provide application information. In addition, for Operators whose discharges are authorized under this permit, any notice will set a deadline to file the permit application and will include a statement that on the effective date of the NPDES individual permit, coverage under this general permit will terminate. EPA may grant additional time to submit the application if an Operator submits a request setting forth reasonable grounds for additional time. If the Operator is covered under this permit and fails to submit an NPDES individual permit application as required by EPA, the applicability of this permit to such Operator is terminated at the end of the day specified by EPA as the deadline for application submittal. chunks.content:
If an Operator does not want to be covered by this general permit but needs permit coverage, the Operator can apply for an NPDES individual permit. In such a case, the Operator must submit an individual permit application in accordance with the requirements of 40 CFR 122.26(c)(1)(ii), with reasons supporting the request, to EPA at the applicable EPA Regional Office listed in Part 8. The request may be granted by issuance of an NPDES individual permit or authorization of coverage under an alternative NPDES general permit.

When an individual NPDES permit is issued or the Operator is authorized under an alternative NPDES general permit to discharge a pollutant to waters of the United States as a result of a pesticide application, authorization to discharge under this permit is terminated on the effective date of the NPDES individual permit or the date of authorization of coverage under the alternative NPDES general permit.

Invalidation of a portion of this permit does not render the whole permit invalid. EPA's intent is that the permit will remain in effect to the extent possible; if any part of this
permit is invalidated, the remaining parts of the permit will remain in effect unless EPA issues a written statement indicating otherwise.

header_path.name: Appendices
1.4 Severability

metadata.Header 1: Appendices

chunks.content: Operators must comply with all other applicable federal and state (including territorial) laws and regulations that pertain to the application of pesticides. For example, this permit does not negate the requirements under the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide, and Rodenticide Act (FIFRA) and its implementing regulations to use registered pesticides consistent with the product's labeling. Operators are advised of their monitoring obligations under FIFRA that, among other things, provide protections for water supplies. In fact, applications in violation of certain FIFRA requirements could also be a violation of the permit and therefore a violation of the CWA (e.g., exceeding label application rates). Additionally, other laws and regulations might apply to certain activities that are also covered under this permit (e.g., United States Coast Guard regulations).

- a. ESA Section 7 consultation that Operators have completed with FWS and/or NMFS as a result of a separate federal action, and/or
- b. ESA Section 10 permit issued to the Operator by FWS and/or NMFS as a result of a separate federal action.

chunks.content:
This Part includes technology-based effluent limitations applicable to all Operators as defined in Appendix A for any discharges authorized under this permit, with compliance required upon beginning such discharge. All Operators are classified as either “Applicators” or “Decision-makers,” as defined in Appendix A, or both. Applicators must perform the tasks identified in Part 2.1 – Applicators’ Responsibilities. Decision-makers must perform the tasks identified in Part 2.2 – Decision-makers’ Responsibilities. There may be instances when a single entity acts as both an Applicator and a Decision-maker.

If an Operator’s discharge of pollutants results from the application of pesticide that is being used solely for the purpose of “pesticide research and development,” as defined in Appendix A, the Operator must use such pesticide consistent with any applicable research plan and experimental use permit.

header_path.name: 2.0 Technology-Based Effluent Limitations

metadata.Header 1: 2.0 Technology-Based Effluent Limitations

chunks.content: As stated in Part 1.5, this permit requires all Operators to comply with all other applicable federal or state laws and regulations that pertain to application of pesticides by the Operator.

header_path.name: 2.0 Technology-Based Effluent Limitations

metadata.Header 1: 2.0 Technology-Based Effluent Limitations

chunks.content:
To meet the effluent limitations of this permit, all Applicators must implement Part 2.1 to minimize the discharge of pesticides to waters of the United States from the application of pesticides, through the use of Pest Management Measures as defined in Appendix A.

- 2.1.1 To the extent not determined by the Decision-maker, use only the amount of pesticide and frequency of pesticide application necessary to control the target pest, using equipment and application procedures appropriate for this task.
- 2.1.2 Maintain pesticide application equipment in proper operating condition, including requirement to calibrate, clean, and repair such equipment and prevent leaks, spills, or other unintended discharges.
- 2.1.3 Assess weather conditions (e.g., temperature, precipitation, and wind speed) in the treatment area to ensure application is consistent with all applicable federal requirements.

header_path.name: 2.0 Technology-Based Effluent Limitations
2.1 Applicators’ Responsibilities

metadata.Header 1: 2.0 Technology-Based Effluent Limitations

chunks.content:
To meet the effluent limitations of this permit, all Decision-makers must implement Part 2.2 to minimize the discharge of pesticides to waters of the United States from the application of pesticides, through the use of Pest Management Measures as defined in Appendix A.

To the extent the Decision-maker determines the amount of pesticide or frequency of pesticide application, the Decision-maker must use only the amount of pesticide and frequency of pesticide application necessary to control the target pest.

Decision-Maker’s Responsibilities: For Any Decision-maker Who is, or Will be Required to Submit an NOI.
